title: Liouville Results and Asymptotics of Solutions of a Quasilinear Elliptic Equation with Supercritical Source Gradient Term
abstract: Abstract We consider the elliptic quasilinear equation <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:msub> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œî</m:mi> <m:mi>m</m:mi> </m:msub> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:msup> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚àá</m:mo> <m:mo>‚Å°</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mi>q</m:mi> </m:msup> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {-\Delta_{m}u=u^{p}\lvert\nabla u\rvert^{q}} in <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi> <m:mi>N</m:mi> </m:msup> </m:math> {\mathbb{R}^{N}} , <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>q</m:mi> <m:mo>‚â•</m:mo> <m:mi>m</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:math> {q\geq m} and <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> {p>0} , <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mn>1</m:mn> <m:mo><</m:mo> <m:mi>m</m:mi> <m:mo><</m:mo> <m:mi>N</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:math> {1<m<N} . Our main result is a Liouville-type property, namely, all the positive <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mi>C</m:mi> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:msup> </m:math> {C^{1}} solutions in <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi> <m:mi>N</m:mi> </m:msup> </m:math> {\mathbb{R}^{N}} are constant. We also give their asymptotic behaviour; all the solutions in an exterior domain <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi> <m:mi>N</m:mi> </m:msup> <m:mo>‚àñ</m:mo> <m:msub> <m:mi>B</m:mi> <m:msub> <m:mi>r</m:mi> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:msub> </m:msub> </m:mrow> </m:math> {\mathbb{R}^{N}\setminus B_{r_{0}}} are bounded. The solutions in <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:msub> <m:mi>B</m:mi> <m:msub> <m:mi>r</m:mi> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:msub> </m:msub> <m:mo>‚àñ</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">{</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo stretchy="false">}</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {B_{r_{0}}\setminus\{0\}} can be extended as continuous functions in <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msub> <m:mi>B</m:mi> <m:msub> <m:mi>r</m:mi> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:msub> </m:msub> </m:math> {B_{r_{0}}} . The solutions in <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi> <m:mi>N</m:mi> </m:msup> <m:mo>‚àñ</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">{</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo stretchy="false">}</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {\mathbb{R}^{N}\setminus\{0\}} has a finite limit <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>l</m:mi> <m:mo>‚â•</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> {l\geq 0} as <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</m:mo> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo>‚Üí</m:mo> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">‚àû</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:math> {\lvert x\rvert\to\infty} . Our main argument is a Bernstein estimate of the gradient of a power of the solution, combined with a precise Osserman-type estimate for the equation satisfied by the gradient.

title: A Priori Bounds and Existence of Solutions for Slightly Superlinear Elliptic Problems
authors: Jorge Garc√≠a-Meli√°n; Leonelo Iturriaga; Humberto Ramos Quoirin
abstract: Abstract We consider the semilinear elliptic problem where a is a continuous function which may change sign and f is superlinear but does not satisfy the standard Ambrosetti-Rabinowitz condition. We show that if f is regularly varying of index one at infinity then the above problem has a positive solution, provided Œ± satisfies some additional assumptions. Our proof uses an abstract theorem due to L. Jeanjean on critical points of functionals with mountain-pass structure, and it relies on the obtention of a priori bounds for positive solutions..

title: Some Remarks on the Duality Method for Integro-Differential Equations with Measure Data
abstract: We deal with existence, uniqueness, and regularity for solutions of the boundary value problem $$ \begin{cases} {\mathcal L}^s u = \mu &\quad \text{in $\Omega$}, u(x)=0 \quad &\text{on} \ \ \mathbb{R}^N\backslash\Omega, \end{cases} $$ where $\Omega$ is a bounded domain of $\mathbb{R}^N$, $\mu$ is a bounded radon measure on $\Omega$, and ${\mathcal L}^s$ is a nonlocal operator of fractional order $s$ whose kernel $K$ is comparable with the one of the factional laplacian.

title: LpHardy's identities and inequalities for Dunkl operators
abstract: Abstract The main purpose of this article is to establish the <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:msup><m:mrow><m:mi>L</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mi>p</m:mi></m:mrow></m:msup></m:math> {L}^{p} Hardy‚Äôs identities and inequalities for Dunkl operator on any finite balls and the entire space <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:msup><m:mrow><m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mi>N</m:mi></m:mrow></m:msup></m:math> {{\mathbb{R}}}^{N} . We also prove Hardy‚Äôs identities and inequalities on certain domains with distance function to the boundary <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:mo>‚àÇ</m:mo><m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ©</m:mi></m:math> \partial \Omega . In particular, we use the notion of Bessel pairs introduced in Ghoussoub and Moradifam to extend Hardy‚Äôs identities for the classical gradients obtained by Lam et al., Duy et al., Flynn et al. to Dunkl gradients introduced by Dunkl. Our Hardy‚Äôs identities with explicit Bessel pairs significantly improve many existing Hardy‚Äôs inequalities for Dunkl operators.

title: Concentration-compactness principle associated with Adams' inequality in Lorentz-Sobolev space
abstract: Abstract The concentration-compactness principle of Lions type in Euclidean space relies on the P√≥lya-Szeg√∂ inequality, which is not available in non-Euclidean settings. The first proof of the concentration-compactness principle in non-Euclidean setting, such as the Heisenberg group, was given by Li et al. by using a symmetrization-free nonsmooth truncation argument. In this article, we study the concentration-compactness principle of second-order Adams‚Äô inequality in Lorentz-Sobolev space <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msubsup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>W</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msubsup> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>L</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>q</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ©</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> {W}_{0}^{2}{L}^{2,q}(\Omega ) for all <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mn>1</m:mn> <m:mo><</m:mo> <m:mi>q</m:mi> <m:mo><</m:mo> <m:mi>‚àû</m:mi> </m:math> 1\lt q\lt \infty . Due to the absence of the P√≥lya-Szeg√∂ inequality with respect to the second-order derivatives, we will use a symmetrization-free argument to study the concentration-compactness principle of second-order Adams‚Äô inequality in Lorentz-Sobolev space. Furthermore, we show the sharpness of result by constructing a test function sequence. Our result is even new in the first-order case when <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>q</m:mi> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:math> q\gt 2 .

title: Global bifurcation of coexistence states for a prey-predator model with prey-taxis/predator-taxis
abstract: Abstract This article is concerned with the stationary problem for a prey-predator model with prey-taxis/predator-taxis under homogeneous Dirichlet boundary conditions, where the interaction is governed by a Beddington-DeAngelis functional response. We make a detailed description of the global bifurcation structure of coexistence states and find the ranges of parameters for which there exist coexistence states. At the same time, some sufficient conditions for the nonexistence of coexistence states are also established. Our method of analysis uses the idea developed by Cintra et al. ( Unilateral global bifurcation for a class of quasilinear elliptic systems and applications , J. Differential Equations 267 (2019), 619‚Äì657). Our results indicate that the presence of prey-taxis/predator-taxis makes mathematical analysis more difficult, and the Beddington-DeAngelis functional response leads to some different phenomena.

title: A Note on Regularity of Solutions to Degenerate Elliptic Equations of Caffarelli-Kohn-Nirenberg Type
abstract: Abstract We establish H√∂lder continuity of weak solutions to degenerate critical elliptic equations of Caffarelli-Kohn-Nirenberg type.

title: Twist Solutions of a Hill's Equation with Singular Term
abstract: Abstract The paper deals with the existence of twist solutions of a Hill's equation with singular term (often called Brillouin equation in the related literature) for a given region of parameters involved on the equation. Solutions of twist type are in particular Lyapunov stable and present interesting dynamical features around them. The techniques of proof include upper and lower solutions, topological degree and classical tools on normal forms of area preserving maps.

title: Solitary Waves with Non-Vanishing Angular Momentum
abstract: Abstract In this paper we prove the existence of infinitely many solitary waves with non vanishing angular momentum for Nonlinear Schr√∂dinger Equation: where œà, : ‚Ñù 3 √ó ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚ÑÇ and 2 < p < 6.

title: Multiple Solutions for Perturbed Elliptic Equations in Unbounded Domains
abstract: Abstract We look for solutions of a nonlinear perturbed Schr√∂dinger equation with nonhomogeneous Dirichlet boundary conditions. By using a perturbation method introduced by Bolle, we prove the existence of multiple solutions in spite of the lack of the symmetry of the problem.

title: Stability of travelling waves for degenerate reaction-diffusion equations of KPP-type
abstract: Abstract The aim of this paper is to investigate the asymptotic behaviour as t ‚Üí ‚àû of the solutions to the Cauchy problem for the nonlinear degenerate KPP-type diffusion-reaction equation u t = (u m ) xx + u p - u q , where m,p and q are positive parameters. Our result is similar to the corresponding one of Kolmogorov, Petrowsky and Piscunov; namely, we prove that for a wide class of initial functions, the solution approaches V(x - c*t) as t ‚Üí ‚àû uniformly in x, where V is a travelling-wave solution with a minimal speed c*.

title: A Seven-Positive-Solutions Theorem for a Superlinear Problem
authors: Marcellino Gaudenzi; Patrick Habets; Fabio Zanolin
abstract: Abstract We consider the superlinear boundary value problem u ∫ + a Œº (t)u Œ≥+1 = 0, u(0) = 0, u(1) = 0, where Œ≥ > 0 and a Œº (t) is a sign indefinite weight of the form a + (t)‚àíŒºa ‚àí (t). We prove, for Œº positive and large, the existence of 2 k ‚àí 1 positive solutions where k is the number of positive humps of a Œº (t) which are separated by k ‚àí 1 negative humps. For sake of simplicity, the proof is carried on for the case k = 3 yielding to 7 positive solutions. Our main argument combines a modified shooting method in the phase plane with some properties of the blow up solutions in the intervals where the weight function is negative.

title: Necessary and Sufficient Conditions for Extinction of One Species
abstract: Abstract In this paper we consider n+1 competing species such that n of them are permanent and we study the behavior of the rest of the species. Our study complements a work initiated by S. Ahmad and A.C. Lazer concerning the extinction or persistence of the rest species.

title: Isolated Singularities of Solutions of Quasilinear Anisotropic Elliptic Equations
authors: Yuliya Namlyeyeva; Andrey Shishkov; Igor I. Skrypnik
abstract: Abstract We consider a wide class of degenerate quasilinear second order elliptic equations with model representative , whose solutions have singularity at a point. There are established sharp point-wise conditions for removable isolated singularity of solutions of such equations. For solutions with non-removable point singularity (source type or fundamental solution), precise upper and lower estimates near the singularity point are obtained.

title: On Existence of L<sup>‚àû</sup>-Ground States for Singular Elliptic Equations in the Presence of a Strongly Nonlinear Term
authors: J.V. Gon√ßalves; Ant√¥nio Luiz de Melo; Carlos Alberto Santos
abstract: Abstract We establish new results concerning existence and the behavior at infinity of solutions for the singular nonlinear elliptic equation ‚àíŒîu = œÅa(x)u ‚àíŒ± + Œªb(x)u Œ≥ in ‚Ñù N , where a, b are nonnegative H√∂lder continuous functions with a + b > 0, Œ±,Œ≥ > 0 are constants and œÅ, Œ≥ are positive parameters. We emphasize that powers u Œ≥ with Œ≥ ‚â§ 1 were treated earlier by a number of authors. Our results address mainly terms u Œ≥ , where Œ≥ is any number bigger than one which we name strongly nonlinear. Penalty arguments, variational principles and an approximation procedure will be exploited.

title: Solutions in Exterior Domains of Null Mass Nonlinear Field Equations
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we are concerned with the existence of solutions of the problem: where Œ© ‚äÇ ‚Ñù N is an exterior domain and f‚Ä≥(0) = 0.

title: On a ‚ÄúZero Mass‚Äù Nonlinear Schr√∂dinger Equation
abstract: Abstract We look for positive solutions to the nonlinear Schr√∂dinger equation ‚àí∆ê 2 ‚àÜu ‚àí V (x)f‚Ä≤(u) = 0 in ‚Ñù N , where V is a continuous bounded positive potential and f satisfies particular growth conditions which make our problem fall in the so called ‚Äúzero mass case‚Äù. We prove an existence result for any ∆ê > 0, and a multiplicity result for ∆ê sufficiently small.

title: Perturbation of Symmetry and Multiplicity of Solutions For Strongly Indefinite Elliptic Systems
abstract: Abstract We consider the following elliptic system: where Œ© ‚äÇ ‚Ñù N , N ‚â• 3 is a smooth bounded domain. If h(x) ‚â° k(x) ‚â° 0, the system presents a natural ‚Ñ§ 2 symmetry, which guarantees the existence of infinitely many solutions. In this paper we show that the multiplicity structure can be maintained if (p,q) lies below a suitable curve in ‚Ñù 2 .

title: Elliptic Obstacle Problems With Natural Growth on the Gradient and Singular Nonlinear Term
authors: David Arcoya; Jos√© Carmona; Pedro J. Mart√≠nez‚àíAparicio
abstract: Abstract Given a bounded, open set Œ© in ‚Ñù N (N ‚â• 3), œà‚àà W 1,p (Œ©) (p > N) such that œÖÃ∏ + ‚àà H 0 1 (Œ©) ‚à© L ‚àû (Œ©) and a suitable strictly positive (see (1.4)) function a ‚àà L q (Œ©) with q > N/2, we prove the existence of positive solution w ‚àà H 0 1 (Œ©) of some variational inequality with a singular nonlinearity whose typical model is where the set of test functions K 1 consists of all functions œÖ ‚àà H 0 1 (Œ©) ‚à© L ‚àû (Œ©) such that œÖ(x) ‚â• œà(x) a.e. x ‚àà Œ© and supp (œÖ - œà+) ‚äÇ‚äÇ Œ©. Bigger classes of test functions are also studied. We also recover the case in which the variational inequality reduces to an equation.

title: On the Poincar√©-Hopf Theorem for Functionals Defined on Banach Spaces
abstract: Abstract Let X be a reflexive Banach space and f : X ‚Üí ‚Ñù a G√¢teaux differentiable function with f‚Ä≤ demicontinuous and locally of class (S) + . We prove that each isolated critical point of f has critical groups of finite type and that the Poincar√©-Hopf formula holds. We also show that quasilinear elliptic equations at critical growth are covered by this result.

title: On Some Quasilinear Critical Problems
abstract: Abstract In this paper we prove the almost everywhere convergence of the gradient of Palais-Smale sequences, allowing us to apply the Brezis-Lieb lemma. This leads us to show that infima are attained, and thus to prove the existence of optimal solutions for some critical problems. Our method does not use the concentration- compactness principle.

title: Variational Inequalities with General Multivalued Lower Order Terms Given by Integrals
abstract: Abstract This paper is about the existence and some properties of solutions of variational inequalities associated with the 2nd order inclusion div[A(x, ‚àáu)] + L ‚àà f (x, u) in Œ©, where the lower order term f (x, u) is a general multivalued function. Both coercive and noncoercive cases are considered. In the noncoercive case, we use a sub-supersolution approach to study the existence, comparison, and other properties of the solution set such as its compactness, directedness, and the existence of extremal solutions.

title: Quasilinear Elliptic Equations on Half- and Quarter-spaces
authors: E. N. Dancer; Yihong Du; Messoud Efendiev
abstract: Abstract We consider quasilinear elliptic problems of the form Œî p u + f(u) = 0 over the half-space H = {x ‚àà ‚Ñù N : x 1 > 0} and over the quarter-space Q = {x ‚àà ‚Ñù N : x 1 > 0, x N > 0}. In the half-space case we assume u ‚â• 0 on ‚àÇH, and in the quarter-space case we assume that u ‚â• 0 on {x 1 = 0} and u = 0 on {x N = 0}. Let u ‚â¢ 0 be a bounded nonnegative solution. For some general classes of nonlinearities f , we show that, in the half-space case, lim x1‚Üí‚àû u(x 1 , x 2 , ..., x N ) always exists and is a positive zero of f ; and in the quarter-space case, where V is a solution of the one-dimensional problem Œî p V + f(V) = 0 in ‚Ñù + , V(0) = 0, V(t) > 0 for t > 0, V(+‚àû) = z, with z a positive zero of f . Our results extend most of those in the recent paper of Efendiev and Hamel [6] for the special case p = 2 to the general case p > 1. Moreover, by making use of a sharper Liouville type theorem, some of the results in [6] are improved. To overcome the difficulty of the lack of a strong comparison principle for p-Laplacian problems, we employ a weak sweeping principle.

title: Min-Max Solutions to Some Scalar Field Equations
abstract: Abstract We show the variational structure of a multiplicity result of positive solutions u ‚àà H 1 (‚Ñù N ) to the equation ‚àíŒîu + a(x)u = u p , where N ‚â• 2, p > 1 with p < 2‚àó ‚àí 1 = and the potential a(x) is a positive function enjoying a planar symmetry. We require suitable decay assumptions which are widely implied by those in [6], in which Wei and Yan have obtained an analogous multiplicity result by using different techniques.

title: Existence of a Least Energy Nodal Solution for a Class of p&q-Quasilinear Elliptic Equations
abstract: Abstract In this paper we prove an existence result for a least energy nodal (or sign-changing) solution for the class of p&q problems given by where Œ© is a smooth bounded domain in ‚Ñù N , N ‚â• 3 and 2 ‚â§ p < N. The function a : ‚Ñù + ‚Üí ‚Ñù + grows like as t ‚Üí +‚àû for some p ‚â§ q < N, the case q = p meaning that a is bounded away from zero and infinity. The nonlinearity f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù grows like |t| m-1 at infinity with Moreover, we find that u has exactly two nodal domains or changes sign exactly once in Œ©. The functions f and a satisfy suitable additional growth and monotonicity conditions which allow this result to extend previous ones to a larger class of p&q type problems. The proof is based on a minimization argument and a variant of quantitative deformation lemma.

title: Existence of Strictly Positive Solutions for Sublinear Elliptic Problems in Bounded Domains
abstract: Abstract Let Œ© be a smooth bounded domain in RN and let m be a possibly discontinuous and unbounded function that changes sign in Œ©. Let f : [0,‚àû) ‚Üí [0,‚àû) be a nondecreasing continuous function such that k 1 Œæ p ‚â§ f (Œæ) ‚â§ k 2 Œæ p for all Œæ ‚â• 0 and some k 1 , k 2 > 0 and p ‚àà (0, 1). We study existence and nonexistence of strictly positive solutions for nonlinear elliptic problems of the form ‚àíŒîu = m(x) f (u) in Œ©, u = 0 on ‚àÇŒ©.

title: Bounded Solutions for Nonlocal Boundary Value Problems on Lipschitz Manifolds with Boundary
abstract: Abstract We consider nonlinear nonlocal boundary value problems associated with fractional operators (including the fractional p -Laplace and the regional fractional p -Laplace operators) and subject to general (fractional-like) boundary conditions on bounded domains with Lipschitz boundary. Under suitable conditions on the nonlinearities of our system, we establish the existence of bounded solutions and provide explicit <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mi>L</m:mi> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">‚àû</m:mi> </m:msup> </m:math> ${L^{\infty}}$ -estimates of solutions which are optimal with respect to the inhomogeneous ‚Äúsources‚Äù present in the system. As application, these results are shown to apply to a class of nonlinear nonlocal equations for the Dirichlet fractional p -Laplacian and regional fractional p -Laplace with a dissipative nonlinearity, and to a class of semilinear nonlocal boundary value problems with fractional Wentzell‚ÄìRobin boundary conditions corresponding to the so-called fractional Wentzell Laplacian.

title: Existence and Multiplicity of Periodic Solutions for Dirichlet‚ÄìNeumann Boundary Value Problem of a Variable Coefficient Wave Equation
authors: Shuguan Ji; Yang Gao; Wenzhuang Zhu
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we consider the periodic solutions of a variable coefficient wave equation which models the forced vibrations of a nonhomogeneous string and the propagation of seismic waves in nonisotropic media. Under Dirichlet‚ÄìNeumann boundary conditions, we find some important properties for the variable coefficient wave operator. Then, based on these properties, we obtain the existence and multiplicity of periodic solutions by using the Leray‚ÄìSchauder degree theory.

title: Sign-Changing Solutions of Fractional ùëù-Laplacian Problems
authors: Xiaojun Chang; Zhaohu Nie; Zhi-Qiang Wang
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we obtain the existence and multiplicity of sign-changing solutions of the fractional p -Laplacian problems by applying the method of invariant sets of descending flow and minimax theory. In addition, we prove that the problem admits at least one least energy sign-changing solution by combining the Nehari manifold method with the constrained variational method and Brouwer degree theory. Furthermore, the least energy of sign-changing solutions is shown to exceed twice that of the least energy solutions.

title: Non-local Degenerate Diffusion Coefficients Break Down the Components of Positive Solutions
authors: Manuel Delgado; Cristian Morales-Rodrigo; Jo√£o R. Santos J√∫nior; Ant√≥nio Su√°rez
abstract: Abstract This paper deals with nonlinear elliptic problems where the diffusion coefficient is a degenerate non-local term. We show that this degeneration implies the growth of the complexity of the structure of the set of positive solutions of the equation. Specifically, when the reaction term is of logistic type, the continuum of positive solutions breaks into two disjoint pieces. Our approach uses mainly fixed point arguments.

Namely, the existence of global connected components of the set of the positive solutions, emanating from the line of the trivial solutions at the two principal eigenvalues of the linearized problem around 0, is established. The solutions in these components are regular, as long as they are small, while they may develop jump singularities at the nodes of the weight function a , as they become larger, thus showing the possible coexistence along the same component of regular and singular solutions.

title: Sharp Caffarelli‚ÄìKohn‚ÄìNirenberg-Type Inequalities on Carnot Groups
abstract: Abstract The main purpose of this paper is to establish several general Caffarelli‚ÄìKohn‚ÄìNirenberg (CKN) inequalities on Carnot groups G (also known as stratified groups). These CKN inequalities are sharp for certain parameter values. In case G is an Iwasawa group, it is shown here that the <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mi>L</m:mi> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:msup> </m:math> {L^{2}} -CKN inequalities are sharp for all parameter values except one exceptional case. To show this, generalized Kelvin transforms <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msub> <m:mi>K</m:mi> <m:mi>œÉ</m:mi> </m:msub> </m:math> {K_{\sigma}} are introduced and shown to be isometries for certain weighted Sobolev spaces. An interesting transformation formula for the sub-Laplacian with respect to <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msub> <m:mi>K</m:mi> <m:mi>œÉ</m:mi> </m:msub> </m:math> {K_{\sigma}} is also derived. Lastly, these techniques are shown to be valid for establishing CKN-type inequalities with monomial and horizontal norm weights.

title: Limit Cycles Coming from Some Uniform Isochronous Centers
authors: Haihua Liang; Jaume Llibre; Joan Torregrosa
abstract: Abstract This article is about the weak 16th Hilbert problem, i.e. we analyze how many limit cycles can bifurcate from the periodic orbits of a given polynomial differential center when it is perturbed inside a class of polynomial differential systems. More precisely, we consider the uniform isochronous centers <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mover accent="true"> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo>Àô</m:mo> </m:mover> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mi>y</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:msup> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>y</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:msup> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mi>y</m:mi> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:msup> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mi>n</m:mi> </m:msup> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo rspace="12.5pt">,</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mover accent="true"> <m:mi>y</m:mi> <m:mo>Àô</m:mo> </m:mover> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mi>y</m:mi> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:msup> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:msup> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mi>y</m:mi> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:msup> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mi>n</m:mi> </m:msup> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>,</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> $\dot{x}=-y+x^{2}y(x^{2}+y^{2})^{n},\quad\dot{y}=x+xy^{2}(x^{2}+y^{2})^{n},$ of degree <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>n</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mn>3</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> ${2n+3}$ and we perturb them inside the class of all polynomial differential systems of degree <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>n</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mn>3</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> ${2n+3}$ . For <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>n</m:mi> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> ${n=0,1}$ we provide the maximum number of limit cycles, 3 and 8 respectively, that can bifurcate from the periodic orbits of these centers using averaging theory of first order, or equivalently Abelian integrals. For <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>n</m:mi> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> ${n=2}$ we show that at least 12 limit cycles can bifurcate from the periodic orbits of the center.

title: Fourth-order Elliptic Equations
abstract: Abstract We prove an existence result for a fourth order elliptic equation where the associated functional does not satisfy the Palais-Smale condition. We use some truncations argument and L ‚àû -norm estimates.

title: Connecting and Closed Geodesics of a Kropina Metric
authors: Erasmo Caponio; Fabio Giannoni; Antonio Masiello; Stefan Suhr
abstract: We prove some results about existence of connecting and closed geodesics in a manifold endowed with a Kropina metric. These have applications to both null geodesics of spacetimes endowed with a null Killing vector field and Zermelo's navigation problem with critical wind.

title: Aleksandrov reflection for extrinsic geometric flows of Euclidean hypersurfaces
abstract: Abstract We survey some ideas regarding the application of the Aleksandrov reflection method in partial differential equation to extrinsic geometric flows of Euclidean hypersurfaces. In this survey, we mention some related and important recent developments of others on the convergence of noncontracting flows and construction and classification of ancient flows.

title: Stability and critical dimension for Kirchhoff systems in closed manifolds
abstract: Abstract The Kirchhoff equation was proposed in 1883 by Kirchhoff [ Vorlesungen √ºber Mechanik , Leipzig, Teubner, 1883] as an extension of the classical D‚ÄôAlembert‚Äôs wave equation for the vibration of elastic strings. Almost one century later, Jacques Louis Lions [‚ÄúOn some questions in boundary value problems of mathematical physics,‚Äù in Contemporary Developments in Continuum Mechanics and PDE‚Äôs , G. M. de la Penha, and L. A. Medeiros, Eds., Amsterdam, North-Holland, 1978] returned to the equation and proposed a general Kirchhoff equation in arbitrary dimension with external force term which was written as <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" overflow="scroll"> <m:mfrac> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>‚àÇ</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>‚àÇ</m:mi> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>t</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:mrow> </m:mfrac> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mfenced close=")" open="("> <m:mrow> <m:mi>a</m:mi> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mi>b</m:mi> <m:msub> <m:mo>‚à´</m:mo> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ©</m:mi> </m:msub> <m:mo stretchy="false">|</m:mo> <m:mi>‚àá</m:mi> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">|</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">d</m:mi> <m:mi>x</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mfenced> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œî</m:mi> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mi>f</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo>,</m:mo> </m:math> $\frac{{\partial }^{2}u}{\partial {t}^{2}}+\left(a+b{\int }_{{\Omega}}\vert \nabla u{\vert }^{2}\mathrm{d}x\right){\Delta}u=f\left(x,u\right),$ where <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" overflow="scroll"> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œî</m:mi> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mo>‚àí</m:mo> <m:mo form="prefix" movablelimits="false">‚àë</m:mo> <m:mfrac> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>‚àÇ</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>‚àÇ</m:mi> <m:msubsup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>x</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>i</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msubsup> </m:mrow> </m:mfrac> </m:math> ${\Delta}=-\sum \frac{{\partial }^{2}}{\partial {x}_{i}^{2}}$ is the Laplace-Beltrami Euclidean Laplacian. We investigate in this paper a closely related stationary version of this equation, in the case of closed manifolds, when u is vector valued and when f is a pure critical power nonlinearity. We look for the stability of the equations we consider, a question which, in modern nonlinear elliptic PDE theory, has its roots in the seminal work of Gidas and Spruck.

title: The existence and multiplicity of L 2-normalized solutions to nonlinear Schr√∂dinger equations with variable coefficients
abstract: Abstract The existence of L 2 ‚Äìnormalized solutions is studied for the equation <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mo>‚àí</m:mo> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œî</m:mi> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mi>Œº</m:mi> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mi>f</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mtext> </m:mtext> <m:mtext> </m:mtext> <m:mtext>in</m:mtext> <m:mspace width="0.3333em" /> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="bold">R</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>N</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mspace width="1em" /> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚à´</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="bold">R</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>N</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:mrow> </m:msub> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mspace width="0.17em" /> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">d</m:mi> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mi>m</m:mi> <m:mo>.</m:mo> </m:math> $-{\Delta}u+\mu u=f\left(x,u\right)\quad \quad \text{in} {\mathbf{R}}^{N},\quad {\int }_{{\mathbf{R}}^{N}}{u}^{2} \mathrm{d}x=m.$ Here m > 0 and f ( x , s ) are given, f ( x , s ) has the L 2 -subcritical growth and ( Œº , u ) ‚àà R √ó H 1 ( R N ) are unknown. In this paper, we employ the argument in Hirata and Tanaka (‚ÄúNonlinear scalar field equations with L 2 constraint: mountain pass and symmetric mountain pass approaches,‚Äù Adv. Nonlinear Stud. , vol. 19, no. 2, pp. 263‚Äì290, 2019) and find critical points of the Lagrangian function. To obtain critical points of the Lagrangian function, we use the Palais‚ÄìSmale‚ÄìCerami condition instead of Condition (PSP) in Hirata and Tanaka (‚ÄúNonlinear scalar field equations with L 2 constraint: mountain pass and symmetric mountain pass approaches,‚Äù Adv. Nonlinear Stud. , vol. 19, no. 2, pp. 263‚Äì290, 2019). We also prove the multiplicity result under the radial symmetry.

<m:mi>s</m:mi> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mfrac> </m:math> ${p}_{s}^{{\ast}}=\frac{np}{n-sp}$ is the critical Sobolev exponent. Our analysis extends classical works (A. Ambrosetti, H. Brezis, and G. Cerami, ‚ÄúCombined effects of concave and convex nonlinearities in some elliptic problems,‚Äù J. Funct. Anal. , vol. 122, no. 2, pp. 519‚Äì543, 1994, B. Barrios, E. Colorado, R. Servadei, and F. Soria, ‚ÄúA critical fractional equation with concave-convex power nonlinearities,‚Äù Ann. Inst. Henri Poincare Anal. Non Lineaire , vol. 32, no. 4, pp. 875‚Äì900, 2015, J. Garc√≠a Azorero, J. Manfredi, and I. Peral Alonso, ‚ÄúSobolev versus H√∂lder local minimizer and global multiplicity for some quasilinear elliptic equations,‚Äù Commun. Contemp. Math. , vol. 2, no. 3, pp. 385‚Äì404, 2000) to fractional p -Laplacian. Owing to the nonlinear and nonlocal properties of <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" overflow="scroll"> <m:msubsup> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚àí</m:mo> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œî</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>s</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msubsup> </m:math> ${\left(-{\Delta}\right)}_{p}^{s}$ , we need to overcome many difficulties and apply notably different approaches, due to the lack of Picone identity, the stability theory, and the strong comparison principle. We show first a dichotomy result: a positive <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" overflow="scroll"> <m:msubsup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>W</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>s</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msubsup> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ©</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> ${W}_{0}^{s,p}\left({\Omega}\right)$ solution of ( P Œª ) exists if and only if Œª ‚àà (0, Œõ] with an extremal value Œõ ‚àà (0, ‚àû). The <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" overflow="scroll"> <m:msubsup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>W</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>s</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msubsup> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ©</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> ${W}_{0}^{s,p}\left({\Omega}\right)$ regularity for the extremal solution seems to be unknown regardless of whether s = 1 or s ‚àà (0, 1). When p ‚â• 2, p ‚àí 1 < q < p and <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" overflow="scroll"> <m:mi>n</m:mi> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mfrac> <m:mrow> <m:mi>s</m:mi> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>q</m:mi> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>q</m:mi> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> <m:mo>‚àí</m:mo> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mfrac> </m:math> $n{ >}\frac{sp\left(q+1\right)}{q+1-p}$ , we get two positive solutions for ( P Œª ) with small Œª > 0. Here the mountain pass structure is more involved than the classical situations due to the lack of explicit minimizers for the Sobolev embedding, we should proceed carefully and simultaneously the construction of mountain pass geometry and the estimate for mountain pass level. Finally, we show another new result for ( P Œª ) and all p > q > 1: without sign constraint, ( P Œª ) possesses infinitely many solutions when Œª > 0 is small enough. Here we use the <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" overflow="scroll"> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">Z</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msub> </m:math> ${\mathbb{Z}}_{2}$ -genus theory, based on a space decomposition for reflexible and separable Banach spaces, which has its own interest.

title: Periodic solutions for a coupled system of wave equations with x-dependent coefficients
abstract: Abstract This paper is concerned with the periodic solutions for a coupled system of wave equations with x -dependent coefficients. Such a model arises naturally when two waves propagate simultaneously in the nonisotrpic media. In this paper, for the periods having the form <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" overflow="scroll"> <m:mi>T</m:mi> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mfrac> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> <m:mi>a</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àí</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>b</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mfrac> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>a</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>b</m:mi> <m:mspace class="nbsp" width="0.3333em"/> <m:mspace width="0.28em"/> <m:mtext>are positive integers</m:mtext> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> $T=\frac{2a-1}{b}\left(a,b \text{are\,positive\,integers}\right)$ and some types of boundary conditions, we obtain the existence of the time periodic solutions and analyze the asymptotic behaviors as the coupled parameter goes to zero, when the nonlinearities are superlinear and monotone, by using the variational method. In particular, the condition ess inf Œ∑ œ± ( x ) > 0 is not required.

title: Recent Progress in Conformal Geometry
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we describe new results in Contact Form Geometry and Yamabe-type problems. We provide in Contact Form Geometry a new way to use the results of [10] and define a homology. We emphasize the connections with the area of pseudeholomorphic curves. We relate, in Yamabe-type problems, smooth and singular solutions to this kind of equations. These new results indicate that noncompact phenomena should be understood in terms of Configuration Spaces in both directions and more generally in the wider area of Conformal Geometry.

title: Emergence of Waves in a Nonlinear Convection-Reaction-Diffusion Equation
abstract: Abstract In this work we prove that for some class of initial data the solution of the Cauchy problem u t = (u m ) xx + a(u m ) x + u(1 - u m-1 ), x ‚àà ‚Ñù; t > 0 u(0; x) = u 0 (x), u 0 (x) ‚â• 0 approaches the travelling solution, spreading either to the right or to the left, or two travelling waves moving in opposite directions.

title: Some Remarks on Elliptic Equations with Singular Potentials and Mixed Boundary Conditions
authors: Boumediene Abdellaoui; Eduardo Colorado; Ireneo Peral
abstract: Abstract We study the problems where is a smooth bounded domain with 0 ‚àà Œ©, and , mixed boundary condition. Mainly we will be interested in the behavior of the solutions to (0.1) close to the critical constant in the Hardy-Sobolev inequality, Œõ N,Œ≥ (Œ©,Œ£ 1 ).

title: Finite Speed of Propagation in Monostable Degenerate Reaction-Diffusion-Convection Equations
abstract: Abstract We study the existence and properties of travelling wave solutions of the Fisher-KPP reaction-diffusion-convection equation u t + h(u)u x = [D(u)u x ] x + g(u), where the diffusivity D(u) is simply or doubly degenerate. Both the cases when ·∏ä(0) and ·∏ä(1) are possibly zero real values or infinity, are treated. We discuss the effects, due to the presence of a convective term, concerning the property of finite speed of propagation. Moreover, in the doubly degenerate case we show the appearance of new types of profiles and provide their classification according to sharp relations between the nonlinear terms of the model. An application is also presented, concerning the evolution of a bacterial colony.

title: On Algebro-Geometric Solutions of the Camassa-Holm Hierarchy
abstract: Abstract We find global solutions of algebro geometric type for all the equations of a new commuting hierarchy containing the Camassa-Holm equation. This hierarchy is built in analogy to the classical K-dV and AKNS hierarchies. We use a zero curvature method to give recursion formulas. The time evolution of the solutions is completely determined, and the motion on a nonlinear subvariety Œ• of a generalized Jacobian variety is obtained by solving an inverse problem for the Sturm-Liouville equation L(œÜ) = ‚àíœÜ‚Ä≥ + œÜ = ŒªyœÜ. This is the natural setting for the expression of the solutions which depend linearly with respect to t and x, with coordinates on a curvilinear parallelogram contained in such a subvariety œÜ. œÜ is obtained as the restriction of the generalized Abel map I 0 to the space Symm g (R) of unordered g-tuples of points on R, and the nonlinear parallelogram is the image through the restricted generalized Abel map of the moving poles P i (x, t) (i = 1, . . . , g) of the Weyl m-functions m ¬± (x, t, Œª) of the dynamical Sturm-Liouville family of equations L x (œÜ) = ‚àíœÜ‚Ä≥ + œÜ = ŒªœÑ x (y)œÜ, where œÑ is the translation flow. It turns out that the choice of a particular stationary initial condition u g (x, t 0 ) completely determines the solution u(x, t) of all the equations in the hierarchy, as functions of the poles P i (x, t) of the Weyl m-functions corresponding to the family L x of Sturm-Liouville operators, with density function y(x, t) = u xx (x, t)/2 ‚àí 2u(x, t). For every t‚àä‚Ñù, the maps x ‚Ü¶ y(x, t) lie in an isospectral class of the associated family of Sturm-Liouville equations L x (œÜ), and are completely determined by assigning spectral parameters and initial conditions for the poles P i (x, t).

title: Asymptotic Symmetry for a Class of Quasi-Linear Parabolic Problems
authors: Luigi Montoro; Berardino Sciunzi; Marco Squassina
abstract: Abstract We study the symmetry properties of the weak positive solutions to a class of quasi-linear elliptic problems having a variational structure. On this basis, the asymptotic behaviour of global solutions of the corresponding parabolic equations is also investigated. In particular, if the domain is a ball, the elements of the œâ limit set are nonnegative radially symmetric solutions of the stationary problem.

title: Existence of Multiple Solutions for Nonlinear Dirichlet Problems with a Nonhomogeneous Differential Operator
authors: Sophia Th. Kyritsi; Donal 'Regan; Nikolaos S. Papageorgiou
abstract: Abstract We consider nonlinear elliptic problems driven by a nonhomogeneous nonlinear differential operator. Using variational methods combined with Morse theory (critical groups), we prove two multiplicity results establishing three nontrivial smooth solutions. For the semilinear problem (linear differential operator), we produce four nontrivial smooth solutions. In the special case of the p-Laplacian differential operator, our framework of analysis incorporates equations which are resonant at infinity with respect to the principal eigenvalue.

title: On Positive Solutions of Minimal Growth For Singular p-Laplacian With Potential Term
abstract: Abstract Let Œ© be a domain in ‚Ñù d , d ‚â• 2, and 1 < p < ‚àû. Fix V ‚àà L ‚àû loc (Œ©). Consider the functional Q and its G√¢teaux derivative Q π given by It is assumed that Q ‚â• 0 on C 0 ‚àû (Œ©). In a previous paper [22] we discussed relations between the absence of weak coercivity of the functional Q on C 0 ‚àû (Œ©) and the existence of a generalized ground state. In the present paper we study further relationships between functional-analytic properties of the functional Q and properties of positive solutions of the equation Q π(u) = 0.

title: Periodic Perturbations With Delay of Autonomous Differential Equations on Manifolds
abstract: Abstract We apply topological methods to the study of the set of harmonic solutions of periodically perturbed autonomous ordinary differential equations on differentiable manifolds, allowing the perturbing term to contain a fixed delay. In the crucial step, in order to cope with the delay, we define a suitable (infinite dimensional) notion of Poincar√© T-translation operator and prove a formula that, in the unperturbed case, allows the computation of its fixed point index.

title: A Uniqueness Result for Œîu - Œªu + V(‚Éíx‚Éí)u<sup>P</sup> = 0 on ‚Ñù<sup>2</sup>
abstract: Abstract Uniqueness of positive radial solutions decaying at infinity is proved for a class of semilinear elliptic equations on ‚Ñù 2 . Complementary results for the same kind of equations were obtained in the early 90‚Äôs, on ‚Ñù N with N ‚â• 3, and in finite balls of ‚Ñù N with N ‚â• 2. The new result presented here plays a crucial role in the global bifurcation problem, previously studied by the author.

title: Existence and Concentration of Bound States for a p-Laplacian Equation in ‚Ñù<sup>N</sup>
abstract: Abstract We study existence and asymptotic behavior of positive solutions for quasilinear elliptic equations of the form -Œµ p Œî p v + V(x)|v| p-2 v = f(v) in ‚Ñù N , 1 < p < N, as Œµ ‚Üí 0. The potential V : ‚Ñù N ‚Üí ‚Ñù has a positive infimum, inf ‚àÇŒ© V > inf Œ© V for some bounded domain Œ© in ‚Ñù N and f is a subcritical nonlinearity without some growth conditions such as Ambrosetti-Rabinowitz.

title: Bifurcation of Limit Cycles from a Polynomial Degenerate Center
authors: Adriana BuicƒÉ; Jaume Gin√©; Jaume Llibre
abstract: Abstract Using Melnikov functions at any order, we provide upper bounds for the maximum number of limit cycles bifurcating from the period annulus of the degenerate center ·∫ã = ‚àíy((x 2 + y 2 )/2) m and ·∫è = x((x 2 + y 2 )/2) m with m ‚â• 1, when we perturb it inside the whole class of polynomial vector fields of degree n. The positive integers m and n are arbitrary. As far as we know there is only one paper that provide a similar result working with Melnikov functions at any order and perturbing the linear center ·∫ã = ‚àíy, ·∫è = x.

title: Statistical Functional Equations and p-Harmonious Functions
abstract: Abstract Motivated by the mean-value property characterizing harmonic functions and recently established asymptotic statistical formulas characterizing p-harmonic functions, we consider the Dirichlet problem for a functional equation involving a convex combination of the mean and median. We show that this problem has a continuous solution when it has both a subsolution and a supersolution. We demonstrate that solutions of these problems approximate p-harmonic functions and discuss connections with related results of Manfredi, Parviainen and Rossi.

title: Applications of Sub-Supersolution Theorems to Singular Nonlinear Elliptic Problems
abstract: Abstract The results presented here were motivated by several recent papers on singular boundary value problems for semilinear elliptic equations with convection terms. We present extensions which cover singular nonlinear equations (mainly equations involving the p‚àíLaplacian) containing convection terms. The results obtained are proved using sub- and supersolution theorems (motivated by the results in [18, 19, 20, 23]) and the construction of a well-ordered pair of such using a principal eigenfunction of the p‚àíLaplacian.

title: On the Symmetry of Solutions to a k-Hessian Type Equation
abstract: Abstract In this note we prove that if u is a negative solution to a nonlinear elliptic equation involving a Hessian operator, and u is zero on the boundary of a ball, then u is radially symmetric and increasing along the radii.

title: Non-autonomous Eigenvalue Problems with Variable (p 1,p 2)-Growth
authors: Sami Baraket; Souhail Chebbi; Nejmeddine Chorfi; Vicen≈£iu D. RƒÉdulescu
abstract: Abstract We are concerned with the study of a class of non-autonomous eigenvalue problems driven by two non-homogeneous differential operators with variable <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:msub> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:msub> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:msub> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:msub> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> {(p_{1},p_{2})} -growth. The main result of this paper establishes the existence of a continuous spectrum consisting in an unbounded interval and the nonexistence of eigenvalues in a neighbourhood of the origin. The abstract results of this paper are described by two Rayleigh-type quotients and the proofs rely on variational arguments.

title: Monotonicity and Symmetry of Nonnegative Solutions to -Œî u=f(u) in Half-Planes and Strips
abstract: Abstract We consider nonnegative solutions to <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œî</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>f</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> ${-\Delta u=f(u)}$ in half-planes and strips, under zero Dirichlet boundary condition. Exploiting a rotating and sliding line technique, we prove symmetry and monotonicity properties of the solutions, under very general assumptions on the nonlinearity f . In fact, we provide a unified approach that works in all cases: <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>f</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo><</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> ${f(0)<0}$ , <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>f</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> ${f(0)=0}$ or <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>f</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> ${f(0)>0}$ .Furthermore, we make the effort to deal with nonlinearities f that may be not locally-Lipschitz continuous.We also provide explicit examples showing the sharpness of our assumptions on the nonlinear function f .

title: Multiplicity of Positive Solutions for Second Order Nonlinear Dirichlet Problem with One-dimension Minkowski-Curvature Operator
abstract: Abstract In this work, we study the existence and multiplicity of positive solutions for nonlinear Dirichlet problem with one-dimension Minkowski-curvature operator , where k > 0 is a constant, Œª > 0 is a parameter and f : [0,‚àû) ‚Üí ‚Ñù is continuous. We apply the quadrature arguments to prove how changes in the sign of f (u) lead to multiple positive solutions of the above problem for sufficiently large Œª.

title: Entire Solutions with Six-fold Junctions to Elliptic Gradient Systems with Triangle Symmetry
authors: Peter W. Bates; Giorgio Fuscoy; Panayotis Smyrnelis
abstract: Abstract We prove the existence of solutions to three-fold symmetric elliptic systems in ‚Ñù 2 which have six-fold symmetry, asymptotically approaching each of three minima of the potential as |x| ‚Üí ‚àû in two antipodal sectors of angle œÄ/3.

title: Nodal Solutions for a Class of Degenerate Boundary Value Problems
abstract: Abstract This paper studies the existence of nodal solutions for a class of boundary value problems that arise in population dynamics models. These problems are degenerate in the sense that the nonlinear term vanishes in a subinterval of the underlying region. In contrast to the non-degenerate case, in these degenerate situations the structure of the set of nodal solutions might consist of several components, making the analysis of this problem more complicated. This paper provides an initial step towards the solution of this general problem.

title: Elliptic Systems of Schr√∂dinger Type in the Spirit of Benci-Fortunato
abstract: Abstract We study the existence of solutions of elliptic systems of the type and we examine how the structure of the system gives rise to a regularizing effect on the summability of the solutions; following the theory of elliptic (single) equations, the regularizing effect is unexpected.

title: The Regularizing Effect of Lower Order Terms in Elliptic Problems Involving Hardy Potential
authors: Adi Adimurthi; Lucio Boccardo; G. R. Cirmi; Luigi Orsina
abstract: Abstract We study existence and summability of solutions for elliptic problems with a power-like lower order term and a Hardy potential.We prove that, due to the presence of the lower order term, solutions exist and are more summable under weaker assumptions than those needed for the existence without it.

title: The Bahri‚ÄìCoron Theorem for Fractional Yamabe-Type Problems
authors: Wael Abdelhedi; Hichem Chtioui; Hichem Hajaiej
abstract: Abstract We study the following fractional Yamabe-type equation: <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mo>{</m:mo> <m:mtable columnspacing="0pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"> <m:mtr> <m:mtd columnalign="right"> <m:mrow> <m:msub> <m:mi>A</m:mi> <m:mi>s</m:mi> </m:msub> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mtd> <m:mtd columnalign="left"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi /> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mfrac> <m:mrow> <m:mi>n</m:mi> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>s</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>n</m:mi> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>s</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mfrac> </m:msup> </m:mrow> <m:mo>,</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mtd> </m:mtr> <m:mtr> <m:mtd columnalign="right"> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mtd> <m:mtd columnalign="left"> <m:mrow> <m:mi /> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:mtd> <m:mtd /> <m:mtd columnalign="right"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mtext>in </m:mtext> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ©</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>,</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mtd> </m:mtr> <m:mtr> <m:mtd columnalign="right"> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mtd> <m:mtd columnalign="left"> <m:mrow> <m:mi /> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:mtd> <m:mtd /> <m:mtd columnalign="right"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mtext>on </m:mtext> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚àÇ</m:mo> <m:mo>‚Å°</m:mo> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ©</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>,</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mtd> </m:mtr> </m:mtable> </m:mrow> </m:math> \left\{\begin{aligned} \displaystyle A_{s}u&\displaystyle=u^{\frac{n+2s}{n-2s}% },\\ \displaystyle u&\displaystyle>0&&\displaystyle\text{in }\Omega,\\ \displaystyle u&\displaystyle=0&&\displaystyle\text{on }\partial\Omega,\end{% aligned}\right. Here Œ© is a regular bounded domain of <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi> <m:mi>n</m:mi> </m:msup> </m:math> {\mathbb{R}^{n}} , <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>n</m:mi> <m:mo>‚â•</m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> {n\geq 2} , and <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msub> <m:mi>A</m:mi> <m:mi>s</m:mi> </m:msub> </m:math> {A_{s}} , <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>s</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àà</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {s\in(0,1)} , represents the fractional Laplacian operator <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œî</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mi>s</m:mi> </m:msup> </m:math> {(-\Delta)^{s}} in Œ© with zero Dirichlet boundary condition. We investigate the effect of the topology of Œ© on the existence of solutions. Our result can be seen as the fractional counterpart of the Bahri‚ÄìCoron theorem [3].

title: Extremals for Fractional Moser‚ÄìTrudinger Inequalities in Dimension 1 via Harmonic Extensions and Commutator Estimates
abstract: Abstract We prove the existence of extremals for fractional Moser‚ÄìTrudinger inequalities in an interval and on the whole real line. In both cases we use blow-up analysis for the corresponding Euler‚ÄìLagrange equation, which requires new sharp estimates obtained via commutator techniques.

title: Nonzero Positive Solutions of Elliptic Systems with Gradient Dependence and Functional BCs
authors: Stefano Biagi; Alessandro Calamai; Gennaro Infante
abstract: We discuss, by topological methods, the solvability of systems of second-order elliptic differential equations subject to functional boundary conditions under the presence of gradient terms in the nonlinearities. We prove the existence of non-negative solutions and provide a non-existence result. We present some examples to illustrate the applicability of the existence and non-existence results.

title: Some Collision Solutions of the Rectilinear Periodically Forced Kepler Problem
abstract: Abstract In [5], Ortega has analyzed ‚Äúgeneralized‚Äù collision solutions of the periodically forced rectilinear Kepler problem. In this note, we explain a different approach to study these solutions by embedding the non-autonomous Hamiltonian system into the zero-energy level of an autonomous Hamiltonian system and by employing the Levi-Civita regularization to regularize the double collisions. In addition to this, under a certain smoothness hypothesis of the periodic force term, we show that there exists a set of positive measure of generalized quasi-periodic solutions in the extended phase space, each of them accumulated by generalized periodic solutions of the system. The energy of these quasi-periodic solutions can have an arbitrary large absolute value.

title: A Jumping Problem for Some Singular Semilinear Elliptic Equations
authors: Annamaria Canino; Mascia Grandinetti; Berardino Sciunzi
abstract: Abstract We consider a jumping problem for singular semilinear elliptic equations. Existence of two distinct solutions is proved via a truncation argument and exploiting minimax methods to prove the existence of solutions to the truncated problem. In the final step, to pass to the limit, a refined analysis about the behavior of the solutions is required, because of the singular nature of the problem.

title: The limiting Behavior of Solutions to Inhomogeneous Eigenvalue Problems in Orlicz-Sobolev Spaces
authors: Marian Bocea; Mihai MihƒÉilescu; Denisa Stancu‚ÄêDumitru
abstract: Abstract The asymptotic behavior of the sequence {u n } of positive first eigenfunctions for a class of inhomogeneous eigenvalue problems is studied in the setting of Orlicz-Sobolev spaces. After possibly extracting a subsequence, we prove that u n ‚Üí u ‚àû uniformly in Œ© as n‚Üí‚àû, where u ‚àû is a nontrivial viscosity solution of a nonlinear PDE involving the ‚àû-Laplacian.

title: The Multiplicity Problem for Periodic Orbits of Magnetic Flows on the 2-Sphere
authors: Alberto Abbondandolo; Luca Asselle; Gabriele Benedetti; Marco Mazzucchelli; I. A. Taƒ≠manov
abstract: We consider magnetic Tonelli Hamiltonian systems on the cotangent bundle of the 2-sphere, where the magnetic form is not necessarily exact. It is known that, on very low and on high energy levels, these systems may have only finitely many periodic orbits. Our main result asserts that almost all energy levels in a precisely characterized intermediate range $(e_0,e_1)$ possess infinitely many periodic orbits. Such a range of energies is non-empty, for instance, in the physically relevant case where the Tonelli Lagrangian is a kinetic energy and the magnetic form is oscillating (in which case, $e_0=0$ is the minimal energy of the system).

minimizing Lipschitz extension and has a close relationship with the random game named tug-of-war. When the function <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>f</m:mi> </m:math> f satisfies the Keller-Osserman-type condition, we establish the existence of the boundary blow-up viscosity solution. Moreover, for the separable case <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>f</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mi>b</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>x</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mi>g</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> f\left(x,u)=b\left(x)g\left(u) , we establish the asymptotic estimate of the blow-up solution near the boundary under some regular conditions of the domain. Based on the asymptotic estimate and comparison principle, we obtain the uniqueness of the large viscosity solution. During this procedure, we also study the non-existence of the large solution. For the separable case, we show that the Keller-Osserman-type condition is sufficient and necessary for the existence of the boundary blow-up viscosity solution.

title: Boussinesq‚Äôs equation for water waves: the soliton resolution conjecture for Sector IV
abstract: Abstract We consider the Boussinesq equation on the line for a broad class of Schwartz initial data relevant for water waves. In a recent work, we identified ten main sectors describing the asymptotic behavior of the solution, and for each of these sectors we gave an exact expression for the leading asymptotic term in the case when no solitons are present. In this paper, we derive an asymptotic formula in Sector IV, characterized by <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" overflow="scroll"> <m:mfrac> <m:mrow> <m:mi>x</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>t</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mfrac> <m:mo>‚àà</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mfrac> <m:mrow> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:msqrt> <m:mrow> <m:mn>3</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msqrt> </m:mrow> </m:mfrac> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> $\frac{x}{t}\in \left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}},1\right)$ , in the case when solitons are present. In particular, our results provide an exact expression for the soliton-radiation interaction to leading order and a verification of the soliton resolution conjecture for the Boussinesq equation in Sector IV.

title: The Sobolev extension problem on trees and in the plane
abstract: Abstract Let V be a finite tree with radially decaying weights. We show that there exists a set <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" overflow="scroll"> <m:mi>E</m:mi> <m:mo>‚äÇ</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> $E\subset {\mathbb{R}}^{2}$ for which the following two problems are equivalent: (1) Given a (real-valued) function œï on the leaves of V , extend it to a function Œ¶ on all of V so that <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" overflow="scroll"> <m:mo stretchy="false">‚Äñ</m:mo> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ¶</m:mi> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">‚Äñ</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>L</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>1</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>V</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:msub> </m:math> ${\Vert}{\Phi}{{\Vert}}_{{L}^{1,p}\left(V\right)}$ has optimal order of magnitude. Here, L 1, p ( V ) is a weighted Sobolev space on V . (2) Given a function <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" overflow="scroll"> <m:mi>f</m:mi> <m:mo>:</m:mo> <m:mi>E</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Üí</m:mo> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi> </m:math> $f:E\to \mathbb{R}$ , extend it to a function <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" overflow="scroll"> <m:mi>F</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àà</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>L</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> $F\in {L}^{2,p}\left({\mathbb{R}}^{2}\right)$ so that <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" overflow="scroll"> <m:mo stretchy="false">‚Äñ</m:mo> <m:mi>F</m:mi> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">‚Äñ</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>L</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:msub> </m:math> ${\Vert}F{{\Vert}}_{{L}^{2,p}\left({\mathbb{R}}^{2}\right)}$ has optimal order of magnitude.

title: Current perspectives on the Halo Conjecture
abstract: Abstract The Halo Conjecture presents one of the outstanding open problems in the theory of differentiation of integrals. In this paper we discuss the Halo Conjecture and its connections with topics of current interest in harmonic analysis.

title: The interior curvature bounds for a class of curvature quotient equations
abstract: Abstract For elliptic partial differential equations, the pure interior C 2 estimates and Pogorelov type estimates are important issues. In this paper, we study the interior estimates of <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" overflow="scroll"> <m:mrow> <m:mover accent="true"> <m:mrow> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œì</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>k</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msub> </m:mrow> <m:mo>ÃÉ</m:mo> </m:mover> </m:mrow> </m:math> $\tilde {{{\Gamma}}_{k}}$ -admissible solutions for curvature quotient equations <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" overflow="scroll"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mfenced close=")" open="("> <m:mrow> <m:mfrac> <m:mrow> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi>œÉ</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>k</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>Œ∑</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>Œ∫</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi>œÉ</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>l</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>Œ∑</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>Œ∫</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mfrac> </m:mrow> </m:mfenced> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mfrac> <m:mrow> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>k</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àí</m:mo> <m:mi>l</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mfrac> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mi>g</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> ${\left(\frac{{\sigma }_{k}\left(\eta \left(\kappa \right)\right)}{{\sigma }_{l}\left(\eta \left(\kappa \right)\right)}\right)}^{\frac{1}{k-l}}=g\left(x,u\right)$ , and establish the pure interior curvature estimate when l = k ‚àí 1, 0 < k ‚â§ n and Pogorelov type estimate when 0 ‚â§ l < k ‚â§ n .

title: A regularity result for incompressible elastodynamics equations in the ALE coordinates
abstract: Abstract We consider incompressible inviscid elastodynamics equations with a free surface and establish regularity of solutions for these equations. Compared with previous result on this free boundary problem [X. Gu and F. Wang, Well-posedness of the free boundary problem in incompressible elastodynamic under the mixed type stability condition, J. Math. Anal. Appl., 482, (2020), 123529] in space H 3 , we are able to establish regularity in space H 2.5+ Œ¥ upon the Arbitrary Lagrangian-Eulerian (ALE) coordinates. It is achieved by reformulating the system into a new formulation with the ALE coordinates, presenting uniform estimates for the pressure, tangential estimates for the system, as well as curl and divergence estimates.

title: An introduction to the distorted Fourier transform
abstract: Abstract This article is intended as an introduction to the distorted Fourier transform associated with a Schr√∂dinger operator on the line or the half-line. This versatile tool has seen numerous applications in nonlinear PDE in recent years. It typically arises in the asymptotic stability analysis of topological solitons in classical field theory, such as kinks in the sine-Gordon or œï 4 models. The distorted Fourier transform is also a natural technique in the analysis of dispersive equations on manifolds with symmetries. Such models appear in general relativity, for example in the study of waves on a black-hole background. While microlocal methods have proven to be powerful in such applications, the more classical Weyl‚ÄìTitchmarsh spectral theory and with it, the distorted Fourier transform, continue to play an essential role in the analysis of evolution PDEs. This article explain how it can be derived from Stone‚Äôs formula, which also establishes the Plancherel and inversion theorems.

title: Quantization effects for multi-component Ginzburg-Landau vortices
authors: Rejeb Hadiji; Jongmin Han; Juhee Sohn
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we are concerned with n -component Ginzburg-Landau equations on <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" overflow="scroll"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> ${\mathbb{R}}^{2}$ . By introducing a diffusion constant for each component, we discuss that the n -component equations are different from n -copies of the single Ginzburg-Landau equations. Then, the results of Brezis-Merle-Riviere for the single Ginzburg-Landau equation can be nontrivially extended to the multi-component case. First, we show that if the solutions have their gradients in L 2 space, they are trivial solutions. Second, we prove that if the potential is square summable, then it has quantized integrals, i.e., there exists one-to-one correspondence between the possible values of the potential energy and <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" overflow="scroll"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">N</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>n</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> ${\mathbb{N}}^{n}$ . Third, we show that different diffusion coefficients in the system are important to obtain nontrivial solutions of n -component equations.

title: Convergence rates of eigenvalue problems in perforated domains: the case of small volume
abstract: Abstract This paper is concerned with the Dirichlet eigenvalue problem for Laplace operator in a bounded domain with periodic perforation in the case of small volume. We obtain the optimal quantitative error estimates independent of the spectral gaps for an asymptotic expansion, with two leading terms, of Dirichlet eigenvalues. We also establish the convergence rates for the corresponding eigenfunctions. Our approach uses a known reduction to a degenerate elliptic eigenvalue problem for which a quantitative analysis is carried out.

title: The Neumann function and the L p Neumann problem in chord-arc domains
abstract: Abstract We construct the Neumann function in a 1-sided chord-arc domain (i.e., a uniform domain with an Ahlfors regular boundary), and establish size and H√∂lder continuity estimates up to the boundary. We then obtain a Kenig-Pipher type theorem, in which L p solvability of the Neumann problem is shown to yield solvability in L q for 1 < q < p , and in the Hardy space H 1 , in 2-sided chord-arc domains, under suitable background hypotheses.

title: Frontmatter
Matrix weights and a maximal function with exponent 3/2
abstract: Abstract We build an example of a simple sparse operator for which its norm with scalar A 2 weight has linear estimate in <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" overflow="scroll"> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">[</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>w</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">]</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi>A</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msub> </m:mrow> </m:msub> </m:math> ${\left[w\right]}_{{A}_{2}}$ , but whose norm in matrix setting grows at least as <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" overflow="scroll"> <m:msubsup> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">[</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>W</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">]</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="bold">A</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msub> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>3</m:mn> <m:mo>/</m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msubsup> </m:math> ${\left[W\right]}_{{\mathbf{A}}_{2}}^{3/2}$ for specially constructed weights from A 2 . We also demonstrate a matrix weighted maximal function with the same estimate from below.

title: Global Schauder estimates for kinetic Kolmogorov-Fokker-Planck equations
abstract: Abstract We present global Schauder type estimates in all variables and unique solvability results in kinetic H√∂lder spaces for kinetic Kolmogorov-Fokker-Planck (KFP) equations. The leading coefficients are H√∂lder continuous in the x , v variables and are merely measurable in the temporal variable. Our proof is inspired by Campanato‚Äôs approach to Schauder estimates and does not rely on the estimates of the fundamental solution of the KFP operator.

title: Soliton resolution and channels of energy
authors: Charles Collot; Thomas Duyckaerts; Carlos E. Kenig; Frank Merle
abstract: Abstract We survey recent results on soliton resolution for the energy critical nonlinear wave equation.

title: An elliptic problem involving critical Choquard and singular discontinuous nonlinearity
authors: Gurdev C. Anthal; Jacques Giacomoni; K. Sreenadh
abstract: Abstract The present article investigates the existence, multiplicity and regularity of weak solutions of problem involving a combination of critical Hartree-type nonlinearity along with singular and discontinuous nonlinearities (see <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" overflow="scroll"> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="script">P</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>Œª</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msub> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> $\left({\mathcal{P}}_{\lambda }\right)$ below). By applying variational methods and using the notion of generalized gradients for Lipschitz continuous functional, we obtain the existence and the multiplicity of weak solutions for some suitable range of Œª and Œ≥ . Finally by studying the L ‚àû -estimates and boundary behaviour of weak solutions, we prove their H√∂lder and Sobolev regularity.

title: Maximal estimates for strong arithmetic means of Fourier series
abstract: Abstract It is well-understood that partial sums of Fourier series for L 1 functions don‚Äôt necessarily converge to the original function in the pointwise-almost everywhere sense. Estimates for averages of partial sum operators demonstrate that the divergence can be quantified. We establish a bilinear maximal estimate for averages of partial sums projectors.

title: Preface for the special issue in honor of Robert Fefferman
Generalized Gaussian curvature flows related to the Orlicz Gaussian Minkowski problem
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we investigate two anisotropic Gaussian curvature flows. Through establishing the long-time existence and congergence for these two flows, we derive the existence results for the Orlicz-Gaussian Minkowski problem in both origin-symmetric and general convex body settings.

title: On certain trilinear oscillatory integral inequalities
abstract: Abstract Inequalities are established for certain trilinear scalar-valued functionals. These functionals act on measurable functions of one real variable, are defined by integration over two- or three-dimensional spaces, and are controlled in terms of Lebesgue space norms of the functions, and in terms of negative powers of large parameters describing a degree of oscillation. Related sublevel set inequalities are a central element of the analysis.

title: Local analytic integrability for a class of degenerate planar vector fields
authors: Antonio Algaba; M. Reyes; Jaume Gin√©
abstract: Abstract Using the normal form theory and the existence of an algebraic inverse integrating factor we characterize the local analytic integrability of the systems whose quasi-homogeneous leading term is <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" overflow="scroll"> <m:mfenced close=")" open="("> <m:mrow> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi>a</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msub> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>y</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>3</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi>a</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msub> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>x</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>3</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mi>y</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi>b</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msub> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>x</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>5</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi>b</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msub> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>x</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>y</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:mrow> </m:mfenced> </m:math> $\left({a}_{1}{y}^{3}+{a}_{2}{x}^{3}y,{b}_{1}{x}^{5}+{b}_{2}{x}^{2}{y}^{2}\right)$ . More specifically we prove that the analytic integrable vector fields inside such family are orbitally equivalent to a semi-quasi-homogeneus system, that is, are not orbitally equivalent to its lowest-degree quasi-homogeneous term.

title: The initial-value problem for a Gardner-type equation
authors: Jerry L. Bona; Hongqiu Chen; Pablo Bobillo Guerrero; Cristina A. Haidau; Sanja Pantic
