/2}v\left(x\right)=g\left(u\left(x\right),v\left(x\right)\right), x\in {\mathbb{R}}^{n}.\quad \hfill \end{cases}$ Under nature structure conditions on f and g , we classify the positive solutions for the semi-linear elliptic system involving the fractional Laplacian by using the direct method of the moving spheres introducing by W. Chen, Y. Li, and R. Zhang (‚ÄúA direct method of moving spheres on fractional order equations,‚Äù J. Funct. Anal. , vol. 272, pp. 4131‚Äì4157, 2017). In the half space, we establish a Liouville type theorem without any assumption of integrability by combining the direct method of moving planes and moving spheres, which improves the result proved by W. Dai, Z. Liu, and G. Lu (‚ÄúLiouville type theorems for PDE and IE systems involving fractional Laplacian on a half space,‚Äù Potential Anal. , vol. 46, pp. 569‚Äì588, 2017).

title: Segregated solutions for nonlinear Schr√∂dinger systems with a large number of components
abstract: Abstract In this paper we are concerned with the existence of segregated non-radial solutions for nonlinear Schr√∂dinger systems with a large number of components in a weak fully attractive or repulsive regime in presence of a suitable external radial potential.

title: Curvature conditions, Liouville-type theorems and Harnack inequalities for a nonlinear parabolic equation on smooth metric measure spaces
abstract: Abstract In this paper we prove gradient estimates of both elliptic and parabolic types, specifically, of Souplet-Zhang, Hamilton and Li-Yau types for positive smooth solutions to a class of nonlinear parabolic equations involving the Witten or drifting Laplacian on smooth metric measure spaces. These estimates are established under various curvature conditions and lower bounds on the generalised Bakry-√âmery Ricci tensor and find utility in proving elliptic and parabolic Harnack-type inequalities as well as general Liouville-type and other global constancy results. Several applications and consequences are presented and discussed.

title: Decay estimates for defocusing energy-critical Hartree equation
authors: Miao Chen; Hua Wang; Xiaohua Yao
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we are devoted to establishing the point-wise decay estimates for solution to the 5D defocusing energy-critical Hartree equation with an initial data in <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>H</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>5</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo>‚à©</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>L</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>5</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> ${H}^{2}({\mathbb{R}}^{5})\cap {L}^{1}({\mathbb{R}}^{5})$ . We show that the nonlinear solution has the same time decay rate as the linear one. The main new ingredient is that we used the theories of Lorentz spaces to overcome the low power of nonlinearity.

title: A surprising property of nonlocal operators: the deregularising effect of nonlocal elements in convolution differential equations
abstract: Abstract We consider nonlocal differential equations with convolution coefficients of the form <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block" overflow="scroll"> <m:mo>‚àí</m:mo> <m:mi>M</m:mi> <m:mfenced close=")" open="("> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>a</m:mi> <m:mspace width="0.17em"/> <m:mo>*</m:mo> <m:mspace width="0.17em"/> <m:mo stretchy="false">|</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">|</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>q</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mi>Œº</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>t</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mfenced> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚Ä≥</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>t</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mi>Œª</m:mi> <m:mi>f</m:mi> <m:mfenced close=")" open="("> <m:mrow> <m:mi>t</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>t</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mfenced> <m:mtext>, </m:mtext> <m:mi>t</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àà</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mn>0,1</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo>,</m:mo> </m:math> $$-M\left(\left(a {\ast} \vert u{\vert }^{q}\right)\left(1\right)\mu \left(t\right)\right){u}^{{\prime\prime}}\left(t\right)=\lambda f\left(t,u\left(t\right)\right)\text{,\,}t\in \left(0,1\right),$$ where q > 0, subject to given boundary data. The function <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" overflow="scroll"> <m:mi>Œº</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àà</m:mo> <m:mi mathvariant="script">C</m:mi> <m:mfenced close=")" open="("> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">[</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mn>0,1</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">]</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mfenced> </m:math> $\mu \in \mathcal{C}\left(\left[0,1\right]\right)$ modulates the strength of the nonlocal element. We demonstrate that the nonlocality has a strong deregularising effect in the specific sense that nonexistence theorems for this problem are directly affected by the magnitude of the function Œº . A specific example illustrates the application of the nonexistence results presented herein.

title: Regularity of center-outward distribution functions in non-convex domains
abstract: Abstract For a probability P in <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" overflow="scroll"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>d</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> ${\mathbb{R}}^{d}$ its center outward distribution function F ¬± , introduced in V. Chernozhukov, A. Galichon, M. Hallin, and M. Henry (‚ÄúMonge‚ÄìKantorovich depth, quantiles, ranks and signs,‚Äù Ann. Stat. , vol. 45, no. 1, pp. 223‚Äì256, 2017) and M. Hallin, E. del Barrio, J. Cuesta-Albertos, and C. Matr√°n (‚ÄúDistribution and quantile functions, ranks and signs in dimension d: a measure transportation approach,‚Äù Ann. Stat. , vol. 49, no. 2, pp. 1139‚Äì1165, 2021), is a new and successful concept of multivariate distribution function based on mass transportation theory. This work proves, for a probability P with density locally bounded away from zero and infinity in its support, the continuity of the center-outward map on the interior of the support of P and the continuity of its inverse, the quantile, Q ¬± . This relaxes the convexity assumption in E. del Barrio, A. Gonz√°lez-Sanz, and M. Hallin (‚ÄúA note on the regularity of optimal-transport-based center-outward distribution and quantile functions,‚Äù J. Multivariate Anal. , vol. 180, p. 104671, 2020). Some important consequences of this continuity are Glivenko‚ÄìCantelli type theorems and characterisation of weak convergence by the stability of the center-outward map.

title: Semilinear Elliptic Systems With Exponential Nonlinearities in Two Dimensions
authors: Djairo G. de Figueiredo; Jo√£o Marcos do √ì; Bernhard Ruf
abstract: Abstract We establish a priori bounds for positive solutions of semilinear elliptic systems of the form where Œ© is a bounded and smooth domain in ‚Ñù 2 . We obtain results concerning such bounds when f and g depend exponentially with respect to u and v.

title: Soliton Solutions to a Class of Quasilinear Elliptic Equations on ‚Ñù
authors: Maria Jos√© De Castro Alves; Paulo C√©sar Carri√£o; Olƒ±ÃÅmpio H. Miyagaki
abstract: Abstract This paper is concerned with the existence of positive solutions for a class of quasilinear elliptic equations on ‚Ñù. The results are proved by combining the concentration-compactness principle due to Lions with a minimization approach.

title: Sobolev Inequalities and Ellipticity of Planar Linear Hamiltonian Systems
abstract: Abstract In this paper we will establish two different classes of ellipticity criteria, called the L p criteria and the L p -L q criteria respectively, for planar linear Hamiltonian systems with periodic coefficients. The criteria are explicitly expressed using the L p and L q norms of coefficients and some known Sobolev constants. These results can be considered as the extensions of the famous Lyapunov stability criterion for Hill‚Äôs equations.

title: Symmetric And Nonsymmetric Solutions For a Class of Quasilinear Schr√∂dinger Equations
abstract: Abstract We use the mountain-pass theorem combined with the principle of symmetric criticality to establish multiplicity of solutions for the class of quasilinear elliptic equations -Œîu + V(z)u - Œî(u 2 )u = h(u) in ‚Ñù N where N ‚â• 4, the potential V : ‚Ñù N ‚Üí ‚Ñù is positive and bounded away from zero and satisfies appropriate periodic and symmetric conditions. The nonlinear term h(u) has subcritical growth and satisfies a condition of the Ambrosetti-Rabinowitz type. Schr√∂dinger equations of this type have been studied as models of several physical phenomena. The nonlinearity here corresponds to the superfluid film equation in plasma physics.

title: Dynamics of Generic Multidimensional Linear Differential Systems
abstract: Abstract We prove that there exists a residual subset R (with respect to the C 0 topology) of d-dimensional linear differential systems based in a Œº-invariant flow and with transition matrix evolving in GL(d,‚Ñù) such that if A ‚àà R, then, for Œº-a.e. point, the Oseledets splitting along the orbit is dominated (uniform projective hyperbolicity) or else the Lyapunov spectrum is trivial. Moreover, in the conservative setting, we obtain the dichotomy: dominated splitting versus zero Lyapunov exponents.

title: On the Fixed Homogeneous Circle Problem
authors: C√©lia Lopes Azevedo; Pedro Ontaneda; Hildeberto E. Cabral
abstract: Abstract We give some results about the dynamics of a particle moving in Euclidean three-space under the influence of the gravitational force induced by a fixed homogeneous circle. Our main results concern (1) singularities and (2) the dynamics in the plane that contains the circle. The study presented here is purely analytic.

title: An Elementary Proof of a Characterization of Constant Functions
authors: Giuseppe De Marco; Carlo Mariconda; Sergio Solimini
abstract: Abstract We give two short and elementary proofs of a characterization of constants function by Brezis. Whereas the original proof involves some refined arguments on Sobolev spaces and BV functions, ours are based either on convolutions or on a sort of nonsmooth Mean Value Theorem which is new to our knowledge.

title: Multiplicity Result for Quasilinear Elliptic Problems with General Growth in the Gradient
abstract: Abstract The main result of this work is to get the existence of infinitely many radial positive solutions to the problem -Œî p u = |‚ñΩu| q + Œªf(x) in Œ©, u|aŒ© = 0, where Œ© = B 1 (0) and f is a radial positive function. Since, in general when q ‚â† p, a Hopf-Cole type change can not be used, we will consider just the existence and multiplicity of positive radial solutions. The main idea is to get a relation between radial positive solutions of the above equation and a suitable quasilinear family of problems with measures data that we will make precise later.

title: Positive Solutions for the p-Laplacian and Bounds for its First Eigenvalue
authors: Hamilton Bueno; Grey Ercole; Ant√¥nio Zumpano
abstract: Abstract We prove a result of existence and localization of positive solutions of the Dirich- let problem for -Œî p u = w(x)f(u) in a bounded domain Œ©, where Œî p is the p-Laplacian, w is a weight function and the nonlinearity f(u) satisfies certain local bounds. As in previous results in radially symmetric domains by two of the authors, and in contrast with the hypotheses usually made, no asymptotic behavior is assumed on f. A positive solution is obtained by applying the Schauder Fixed Point Theorem and such approach allows us to construct ordered sub- and super-solutions for the problem, thus producing an iterative method to obtain a positive solution. Our result leads not only to asymptotic conditions on the nonlinearity which provides the existence of a sequence of positive solutions for the problem with arbitrarily large sup norm, but also to an estimate of the first eigenvalue Œª p (Œ©, w) of the p-Laplacian operator with weight w. For w ‚â° 1, we compare our lower bound for Œª p (Œ©, 1) with that obtained by means of the Cheeger constant h(Œ©). We give a characterization of this constant in terms of the solution of the torsional creep problem -Œî p…∏p = 1 in Œ© with Dirichlet boundary data, which offers a good approximation of the first eigenvalue of the p-Laplacian for p near 1.

title: Existence, Asymptotic Behavior and Uniqueness for Large Solutions to Œîu = e<sup>q(x)u</sup>
authors: Jorge Garc√≠a-Meli√°n; Jos√© C. Sabina de Lis; Julio D. Rossi
abstract: Abstract In this paper we consider existence, asymptotic behavior near the boundary and uniqueness for solutions to Œîu = e q(x)u in a bounded smooth domain Œ© with the boundary condition u(x) ‚Üí + ‚àû as dist(x, ‚àÇŒ©) ‚Üí 0. The exponent q(x) is assumed to be a H√∂lder continuous function which is either positive on ‚àÇŒ© or is positive in a neighborhood of ‚àÇŒ© maybe vanishing on ‚àÇŒ©. When dealing with nonnegative exponents q we are allowing nonempty interior regions Œ© 0 ‚äÇ Œ© where q vanishes. Changing sign exponents q will be also considered.

title: Evolution of Spacelike Hypersurfaces by Mean Curvature Minus External Force Field in Minkowski Space
abstract: Abstract We study the evolution of spacelike hypersurface moving by mean curvature minus an external force field in Minkowski space. It is shown that the flow will exist for all time if the initial spacelike surface has two compact spacelike barrier surfaces and the external force field satisfies a weak convexity condition.

title: Existence of a Positive Solution to a Nonlinear Scalar Field Equation with Zero Mass at Infinity
abstract: Abstract We establish the existence of a positive solution to the problem <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œî</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>V</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>f</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo rspace="12.5pt">,</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àà</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mi>D</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mn>1</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi> <m:mi>N</m:mi> </m:msup> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>,</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> -\Delta u+V(x)u=f(u),\quad u\in D^{1,2}(\mathbb{R}^{N}), for <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>N</m:mi> <m:mo>‚â•</m:mo> <m:mn>3</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> {N\geq 3} , when the nonlinearity f is subcritical at infinity and supercritical near the origin, and the potential V vanishes at infinity. Our result includes situations in which the problem does not have a ground state. Then, under a suitable decay assumption on the potential, we show that the problem has a positive bound state.

title: Optimization of the First Eigenvalue of Equations with Indefinite Weights
authors: Chris Cosner; Fabrizio Cuccu; Giovanni Porru
abstract: Abstract We investigate minimization and maximization of the principal eigenvalue of the Laplacian under Dirichlet boundary conditions in case the weight has indefinite sign and varies in a class of rearrangements. Biologically, such optimization problems are motivated by the question of determining the most convenient spatial arrangement of favorable and unfavorable resources for a species to survive or to decline. The question may have practical importance in the context of reserve design or pest control.

title: Regularizing Effect of a Gradient Term in a Problem Involving the p-Laplacian Operator
abstract: Abstract In this article we consider the following problem with max{p ‚àí 1, 1} ‚â§ q ‚â§ p < N, Œ© a bounded domain and f, g positive measurable functions in Œ©. We give assumptions on g with respect to q and p for which for all Œª > 0 and all f ‚àà L 1 (Œ©), f ‚â• 0, problem (P) has a positive solution. In particular, we focus our attention on the case when 0 ‚àà Œ© and to prove that the assumptions on g are optimal. Furthermore, regularity results are given.

title: Elliptic Variational Inequalities with Discontinuous Multi-Valued Lower Order Terms
abstract: Abstract We consider multi-valued elliptic variational inequalities for operators of the form u ‚Ü¶ Au + ‚àÇ 2 œà(u, u), where A is a second order elliptic operator of Leray-Lions type, and u ‚Ü¶ ‚àÇ 2 œà(u, u) is a multi-valued lower order term that may neither be lower nor upper semicontinuous, see e.g., Figure 2. More precisely, the lower order term is generated by some function (r, s) ‚Üí œà(r, s) with œà : ‚Ñù √ó ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù that is locally Lipschitz with respect to its second variable s for each r ‚àà ‚Ñù, and ‚àÇ 2 œà(r, s) denotes Clarke‚Äôs generalized gradient of s ‚Ü¶ œà(r, s). The novelty of this paper is that the multifunction r ‚Ü¶ ‚àÇ 2 œà(r, s) may discontinuously depend on r in a certain specified way, which gives rise to the new class of discontinuous multi-valued lower order terms s ‚Ü¶ ‚àÇ 2 œà(s, s). Though rich in structure, the characteristic features of this new class of multi-valued lower order terms can easily be described and verified. Our main goal is to provide an analytical framework and to prove existence and comparison results for this new class of multi-valued variational inequalities that includes the theory of variational-hemivariational inequalities as special case.

title: Prevalence of Non-degenerate Periodic Solutions in the Forced Pendulum Equation
abstract: Abstract Many known properties of the forced pendulum equation are generic. This means that they hold on a residual set of forcings. The classical duality category/measure inspires the main question in the paper: are these properties also valid for a prevalent set of forcings? This is the case for a key property: the non-degeneracy of periodic solutions. The main tool in the proof is a prevalent version of the parametric transversality theorem.

title: On Aharonov‚ÄìBohm Operators with Two Colliding Poles
authors: Laura Abatangelo; Veronica Felli; Corentin L√©na
abstract: We consider Aharonov-Bohm operators with two poles and prove sharp asymptotics for simple eigenvalues as the poles collapse at an interior point out of nodal lines of the limit eigenfunction.

title: Relative Nielsen Numbers, Braids and Periodic Segments
abstract: Abstract The aim of this paper is to establish a connection between the method of period segments and the relative Nielsen fixed point theory. We prove that if W is a periodic segment over <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">[</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>T</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">]</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> {[0,T]} for the T -periodic semi-process Œ¶, then the Poincar√© map P has at least <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>N</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:msub> <m:mi>m</m:mi> <m:mi>W</m:mi> </m:msub> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mover accent="true"> <m:mrow> <m:msub> <m:mi>W</m:mi> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:msub> <m:mo>‚àñ</m:mo> <m:msubsup> <m:mi>W</m:mi> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mrow> <m:mi /> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mo>-</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:msubsup> </m:mrow> <m:mo>¬Ø</m:mo> </m:mover> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {N(m_{W},\overline{W_{0}\setminus W_{0}^{--}})} fixed points with trajectories contained in W , where <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>N</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:msub> <m:mi>m</m:mi> <m:mi>W</m:mi> </m:msub> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mover accent="true"> <m:mrow> <m:msub> <m:mi>W</m:mi> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:msub> <m:mo>‚àñ</m:mo> <m:msubsup> <m:mi>W</m:mi> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mrow> <m:mi /> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mo>-</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:msubsup> </m:mrow> <m:mo>¬Ø</m:mo> </m:mover> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {N(m_{W},\overline{W_{0}\setminus W_{0}^{--}})} is the relative Nielsen number defined by Zhao. It is also shown that if the sequence <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>N</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mover accent="true"> <m:mi>m</m:mi> <m:mo>¬Ø</m:mo> </m:mover> <m:mi>n</m:mi> </m:msup> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {N(\overline{m}^{n})} is bounded and <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mi>N</m:mi> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">‚àû</m:mi> </m:msup> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mi>m</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> {N^{\infty}(m)>1} , then the Poincar√© map has infinitely many periodic points. We prove that there exists a compact set <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>I</m:mi> <m:mo>‚äÇ</m:mo> <m:msub> <m:mi>W</m:mi> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:msub> </m:mrow> </m:math> {I\subset W_{0}} , invariant for the Poincar√© map, such that the topological entropy <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>h</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi>P</m:mi> <m:mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mi>I</m:mi> </m:msub> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {h(P|_{I})} is bounded from below by <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>log</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å°</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mi>N</m:mi> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">‚àû</m:mi> </m:msup> </m:mrow> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mi>m</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>h</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mover accent="true"> <m:mi>m</m:mi> <m:mo>¬Ø</m:mo> </m:mover> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {\log N^{\infty}(m)-h(\overline{m})} . In particular, if <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>h</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mover accent="true"> <m:mi>m</m:mi> <m:mo>¬Ø</m:mo> </m:mover> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> {h(\overline{m})=0} , then <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>h</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi>P</m:mi> <m:mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mi>I</m:mi> </m:msub> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>‚â•</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>log</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å°</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mi>N</m:mi> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">‚àû</m:mi> </m:msup> </m:mrow> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mi>m</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>.</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> {h(P|_{I})\geq\log N^{\infty}(m).} We adapt the result obtained by Jiang to get a concrete example of a braid-like periodic segment with <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mi>N</m:mi> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">‚àû</m:mi> </m:msup> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mi>m</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> {N^{\infty}(m)>1} .

title: Multiplicity of Solutions to Elliptic Problems Involving the 1-Laplacian with a Critical Gradient Term
authors: Boumediene Abdellaoui; Andrea Dall‚ÄôAglio; Sergio Segura de Le√≥n
abstract: Abstract In the present paper we study the Dirichlet problem for an equation involving the 1-Laplacian and a total variation term as reaction.We prove a strong multiplicity result. Namely, we show that for any positive Radon measure concentrated in a set away from the boundary and singular with respect to a certain capacity, there exists an unbounded solution, and measures supported on disjoint sets generate different solutions.These results can be viewed as the analogue for the 1-Laplacian operator of some known multiplicity results which were first obtained by Ireneo Peral, to whom this article is dedicated, and his collaborators.

title: A General Approximation Approach for the Simultaneous Treatment of Integral and Discrete Operators
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we give a unitary approach for the simultaneous study of the convergence of discrete and integral operators described by means of a family of linear continuous functionals acting on functions defined on locally compact Hausdorff topological groups. The general family of operators introduced and studied includes very well-known operators in the literature. We give results of uniform convergence and modular convergence in the general setting of Orlicz spaces. The latter result allows us to cover many other settings as the <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:msup><m:mi>L</m:mi><m:mi>p</m:mi></m:msup></m:math> {L^{p}} -spaces, the interpolation spaces, the exponential spaces and many others.

title: Finite-Dimensionality and Determining Modes of the Global Attractor for 2D Boussinesq Equations with Fractional Laplacian
authors: Aimin Huang; Wenru Huo; Michael S. Jolly
abstract: Abstract We prove the finite dimensionality of the global attractor and estimate the numbers of the determining modes for the 2D Boussinesq system in a periodic domain with fractional Laplacian in the subcritical case.

Then this result is applied to discuss the nature of the territorial refuges in periodic competitive environments.

title: Convergence Rates in a Weighted Fuƒçik Problem
abstract: Abstract In this work we consider the Fuƒçik problem for a family of weights depending on Œµ with Dirichlet and Neumann boundary conditions. We study the homogenization of the spectrum. We also deal with the special case of periodic homogenization and we obtain the rate of convergence of the first non-trivial curve of the spectrum.

abstract: Abstract In this paper, we consider the dynamics for damped generalized incompressible Navier‚ÄìStokes equations defined on <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:msup> </m:math> ${\mathbb{R}^{2}}$ . title: On Invariant Tori with Prescribed Frequency in Hamiltonian Systems
authors: Dongfeng Zhang; Junxiang Xu; Hao Wu
abstract: Abstract In this paper we are mainly concerned with the persistence of invariant tori with prescribed frequency for analytic nearly integrable Hamiltonian systems under the Brjuno‚ÄìR√ºssmann non-resonant condition, when the Kolmogorov non-degeneracy condition is violated. As it is well known, the frequency of the persisting invariant tori may undergo some drifts, when the Kolmogorov non-degeneracy condition is violated. By the method of introducing external parameters and rational approximations, we prove that if the Brouwer topological degree of the frequency mapping is nonzero at some Brjuno‚ÄìR√ºssmann frequency, then the invariant torus with this frequency persists under small perturbation.

title: Ground States for Nonlinear Schr√∂dinger Equations with a Sign-changing Potential Well
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we consider the ground state solutions for a class of nonlinear Schr√∂dinger equations where 2 < p < 2*. We investigate the case Œª > inf œÉ (‚àíŒî + V), i.e., an indefinite problem. We characterize the ground states as minimizers of the variational functional on a modified Nehari manifold.

title: Existence of Heteroclinic Solutions for a Pseudo-relativistic Allen-Cahn Type Equation
abstract: Abstract We study the existence and uniqueness of heteroclinic solutions to non-linear Allen-Cahn equation where G is a double-well potential. We investigate such a problem using variational methods after transforming the problem to an elliptic equation with a nonlinear Neumann boundary conditions.

title: Asymptotic behavior of solutions to the Monge-Amp√®re equations with slow convergence rate at infinity
abstract: Abstract We consider the asymptotic behavior of solutions to the Monge-Amp√®re equations with slow convergence rate at infinity and fulfill previous results under faster convergence rate by Bao et al. [ Monge-Amp√®re equation on exterior domains , Calc. Var PDE. 52 (2015), 39‚Äì63]. Different from known results, we obtain the limit of Hessian and/or gradient of solution at infinity relying on the convergence rate. The basic idea is to use a revised level set method, the spherical harmonic expansion, and the iteration method.

title: Existence of nonminimal solutions to an inhomogeneous elliptic equation with supercritical nonlinearity
authors: Kazuhiro Ishige; Shinya Okabe; Tokushi Sato
abstract: Abstract In our previous paper [K. Ishige, S. Okabe, and T. Sato, A supercritical scalar field equation with a forcing term , J. Math. Pures Appl. 128 (2019), pp. 183‚Äì212], we proved the existence of a threshold <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>Œ∫</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚àó</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:math> {\kappa }^{\ast }\gt 0 such that the elliptic problem for an inhomogeneous elliptic equation <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mo>‚àí</m:mo> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œî</m:mi> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mi>Œ∫</m:mi> <m:mi>Œº</m:mi> </m:math> -\Delta u+u={u}^{p}+\kappa \mu in <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="bold">R</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>N</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> {{\bf{R}}}^{N} possesses a positive minimal solution decaying at the space infinity if and only if <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo><</m:mo> <m:mi>Œ∫</m:mi> <m:mo>‚â§</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>Œ∫</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚àó</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> 0\lt \kappa \le {\kappa }^{\ast } . Here, <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>N</m:mi> <m:mo>‚â•</m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:math> N\ge 2 , <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>Œº</m:mi> </m:math> \mu is a nontrivial nonnegative Radon measure in <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="bold">R</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>N</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> {{\bf{R}}}^{N} with a compact support, and <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:math> p\gt 1 is in the Joseph-Lundgren subcritical case. In this article, we prove the existence of nonminimal positive solutions to the elliptic problem. Our arguments are also applicable to inhomogeneous semilinear elliptic equations with exponential nonlinearity.

title: Quasilinear problems with nonlinear boundary conditions in higher-dimensional thin domains with corrugated boundaries
authors: Jean Carlos Nakasato; Marcone C. Pereira
abstract: Abstract In this work, we analyze the asymptotic behavior of a class of quasilinear elliptic equations defined in oscillating <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:mrow><m:mo>(</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mi>N</m:mi><m:mo>+</m:mo><m:mn>1</m:mn></m:mrow><m:mo>)</m:mo></m:mrow></m:math> \left(N+1) -dimensional thin domains (i.e., a family of bounded open sets from <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:msup><m:mrow><m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mi>N</m:mi><m:mo>+</m:mo><m:mn>1</m:mn></m:mrow></m:msup></m:math> {{\mathbb{R}}}^{N+1} , with corrugated bounder, which degenerates to an open bounded set in <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:msup><m:mrow><m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mi>N</m:mi></m:mrow></m:msup></m:math> {{\mathbb{R}}}^{N} ). We also allow monotone nonlinear boundary conditions on the rough border whose magnitude depends on the squeezing of the domain. According to the intensity of the roughness and a reaction coefficient term on the nonlinear boundary condition, we obtain different regimes establishing effective homogenized limits in <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:mi>N</m:mi></m:math> N -dimensional open bounded sets. In order to do that, we combine monotone operator analysis techniques and the unfolding method used to deal with asymptotic analysis and homogenization problems.

title: Time-vanishing properties of solutions of some degenerate parabolic equations with strong absorption
abstract: Abstract Let Œ© be an open bounded subset of ‚Ñù N and b a measurable nonnegative function in ‚Ñù. We study the time compact support property for ‚àÇ t u - Œî p u + b(x)u q = 0 with p > 2 and for ‚àÇ t u - Œî(u m ) + b(x)u q = 0 with m > 1 where 0 ‚â§ q < 1. Some criteria involving the asymptotics as h ‚Üí 0 of the first eigenvalue of are given which imply such a phenomenon. Applying these criteria we deduce that the time vanishing property occurs when 1/b belongs to L s (Œ©) for some s depending on q, and p or m.

title: The p-Laplace Heat Equation With a Source Term: Self-similar Solutions Revisited
abstract: Abstract We study the self-similar solutions of any sign of the equation u t - div(|‚ñΩu| p-2 ‚ñΩu) = |u| q-1 u, in ‚Ñù N , where p, q > 1. We extend the results of Haraux-Weissler obtained for p = 2 to the case q > p-1 > 0. In particular we study the existence of slow or fast decaying solutions. For given t > 0, the fast solutions u(t, .) have a compact support in ‚Ñù N when p > 2; and |x| p/(2-p) u(t, x) is bounded at infinity when p < 2: We describe the behaviour for large |x| of all the solutions. According to the position of q with respect to the first critical exponent p - 1 + p/N and the critical Sobolev exponent q*, we study the existence of positive solutions, or the number of the zeros of u(t, .). We prove that any solution u(t, .) is oscillatory when p < 2 and q is closed to 1.

title: Non-Degeneracy and Periodic Solutions of Semilinear Differential Equations with Deviation
authors: Gang Meng; Ping Yan; Xiaoyan Lin; Meirong Zhang
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we will use some Sobolev constants to construct certain classes of nondegenerate potentials for linear differential equations with deviation. As an application of these potentials, we will give some existence results of periodic solutions of semilinear equations with deviation.

title: On Some Results of Moser and of Bangert, II
abstract: Abstract Existence is proved for heteroclinic solutions of a family of semilinear elliptic PDE‚Äôs on ‚Ñù n treated earlier by Bangert [2]. A variational framework for finding solutions of this problem is presented. It will be used in a sequel to construct more complicated homoclinic and heteroclinic solutions of the equation.

title: Solitary Waves for Quasilinear Schr√∂dinger Equations Arising in Plasma Physics
abstract: Abstract We study the quasilinear Schr√∂dinger equation iz t = ‚àí‚àÜz +W(x)z ‚àí Œ∑(|z| 2 )z ‚àí k[‚àÜp(|z| 2 )]p‚Ä≤(|z| 2 )z in ‚Ñù 2 , where W : ‚Ñù 2 ‚Üí‚Ñù is a positive potential and the nonlinearity Œ∑ : ‚Ñù 2 √ó ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù has critical or sub-critical exponential growth. Quasilinear Schr√∂dinger equations of this type have been studied as models of several physical phenomena such as superfluid film equation, in the theory of Heisenberg ferromagnets and magnons, in dissipative quantum mechanics and in condensed matter theory. In a suitable Orlicz space together with Trudinger-Moser inequality we establish an existence of standing wave solutions for this problem. The second order nonlinearity considered in this paper corresponds to the superfluid equation in plasma physics.

title: Radial Solutions for Hamiltonian Elliptic Systems With Weights
authors: Pablo L. De N√°poli; Irene Drelichman; Ricardo G. Dur√°n
abstract: Abstract We prove the existence of infinitely many radial solutions for elliptic systems in ‚Ñù n with power weights. A key tool for the proof will be a weighted imbedding theorem for fractional-order Sobolev spaces, that could be of independent interest.

title: Potential Estimates for Quasi-Linear Parabolic Equations
authors: Vitali Liskevich; Igor I. Skrypnik; Zeev Sobol
abstract: Abstract For a class of divergence type quasi-linear degenerate parabolic equations with a Radon measure on the right hand side we derive pointwise estimates for solutions via nonlinear Wolff potentials.

title: Weak Solutions and Energy Estimates for a Class of Nonlinear Elliptic Neumann Problems
authors: Gabriele Bonanno; Giovanni Molica Bisci; Vicen≈£iu D. RƒÉdulescu
abstract: Abstract We establish existence results and energy estimates of solutions for a homogeneous Neumann problem involving the p-Laplace operator. The case of large dimensions, corresponding to the lack of compactness of W 1,p (Œ©) in C 0 (Œ©ÃÖ) is also considered. In particular, for a precise localization of the parameter, the existence of a non-zero solution is established, without requiring any asymptotic condition at zero or at infinity of the nonlinear term. In the case of (p ‚àí 1)-sublinear terms at the origin, we deduce the existence of solutions for small positive values of the parameter and we obtain that the corresponding solutions have smaller and smaller energies as the parameter goes to zero. Finally, a multiplicity result is obtained and concrete examples of applications are provided. A basic ingredient in our arguments is a recent local minimum theorem for differentiable functionals.

title: Equivalence of Some Multi-Valued Elliptic Variational Inequalities and Variational-Hemivariational Inequalities
abstract: Abstract First, we prove existence and comparison results for multi-valued elliptic variational inequalities involving Clarke‚Äôs generalized gradient of some locally Lipschitz functions as multi-valued term. Only by applying the definition of Clarke‚Äôs gradient it is well known that any solution of such a multi-valued elliptic variational inequality is also a solution of a corresponding variational-hemivariational inequality. The reverse is known to be true if the locally Lipschitz functions are regular in the sense of Clarke. Without imposing this kind of regularity the equivalence of the two problems under consideration is not clear at all. The main goal of this paper is to show that the equivalence still holds true without any additional regularity, which will fill a gap in the literature. Existence and comparison results for both multi-valued variational inequalities and variational-hemivariational inequalities are the main tools in the proof of the equivalence of these problems.

title: Periodic Bouncing Solutions for Nonlinear Impact Oscillators
abstract: Abstract We prove the existence of a periodic solution to a nonlinear impact oscillator, whose restoring force has an asymptotically linear behavior. To this aim, after regularizing the problem, we use phase-plane analysis, and apply the Poincar√©-Bohl fixed point Theorem to the associated Poincar√© map, so to find a periodic solution of the regularized problem. Passing to the limit, we eventually find the ‚Äúbouncing solution‚Äù we are looking for.

title: Quasilinear Elliptic Problems with General Growth and Nonlinear Term Having Singular Behavior
abstract: Abstract In this paper we deal with the following quasilinear elliptic problems where Œ© ‚äÇ ‚Ñù N is a bounded regular domain, d(x) = dist(x, ‚àÇŒ©), p > 1, Œª > 0 and 0 < ŒΩ ‚â§ p. Moreover, g, q and f are nonnegative functions verifying suitable hypotheses. The main goal of this work is to analyze the interaction between the functions d, g and the gradient term to get existence and nonexistence results. The singular behavior of g near 0 will provide a new phenomenon that does not appear in the case where the absorption term g(u) q(d(x)) is dropped or substituted by a regular one.

title: A Note on Vortices with Prescribed Charge
abstract: Abstract We consider the nonlinear Klein-Gordon equation with nonnegative potential, which makes the equation suitable for physical models, and prove the existence of solitary wave solutions with nonvanishing angular momentum and enough largely prescribed charge (c-vortices). This is done by solving the following minimization problem: where x = (y, z) ‚àà ‚Ñù 2 √ó ‚Ñù, k ‚â† 0 and H is a suitable subspace of H 1 (‚Ñù 3 ) √ó ‚Ñù.

title: Multiple Solutions for Nonlinear Neumann Problems with Asymmetric Reaction, via Morse Theory
abstract: Abstract We consider a nonlinear Neumann problem driven by the p-Laplacian and with a reaction which exhibits an asymmetric behaviour near +‚àû and near ‚àí‚àû. Namely, it is (p ‚àí 1)- superlinear near +‚àû (but need not satisfy the Ambrosetti-Rabinowitz condition) and it is (p ‚àí 1)-linear near ‚àí‚àû. Combining variational methods with Morse theory, we show that the problem has at least three nontrivial smooth solutions.

title: Quasilinear Riccati Type Equations and Quasiminimizers
abstract: Abstract Solutions u of the equation -‚àá „Éª A(x, ‚àáu) = b(x)|‚àáu| q are studied in the subcritical case p - 1 ‚â§ q ‚â§ p/n + p - 1, q < p < n. Here A(x, h) satisfies A(x, h) „Éª h ‚âà |h| p and b a bounded function in an open set Œ© ‚äÇ R n . It is shown that the solutions u are local quasiminimizers in Œ©. From the quasiminimizing property several conclusions on the behavior of the solutions u can be derived. In particular, the method provides an easy solution to the uniqueness problem in the class W 0 1,p (Œ©).

title: Singularly Perturbed Fractional Schr√∂dinger Equation Involving a General Critical Nonlinearity
authors: Hua Jin; Wenbin Liu; Jianjun Zhang
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we are concerned with the existence and concentration phenomena of solutions for the following singularly perturbed fractional Schr√∂dinger problem: <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mi>Œµ</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>s</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œî</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mi>s</m:mi> </m:msup> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>V</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>f</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true"> </m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mtext>in </m:mtext> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi> <m:mi>N</m:mi> </m:msup> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>,</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> \varepsilon^{2s}(-\Delta)^{s}u+V(x)u=f(u)\quad\text{in }\mathbb{R}^{N}, where <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>N</m:mi> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>s</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {N>2s} and the nonlinearity f has critical growth. By using the variational approach, we construct a localized bound-state solution concentrating around an isolated component of the positive minimum point of V as <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>Œµ</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Üí</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> {\varepsilon\rightarrow 0} . Our result improves the study made in [X. He and W. Zou, Existence and concentration result for the fractional Schr√∂dinger equations with critical nonlinearities, Calc. Var. Partial Differential Equations 55 2016, 4, Article ID 91], in the sense that, in the present paper, the Ambrosetti‚ÄìRabinowitz condition and the monotonicity condition on <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>f</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mi>t</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>/</m:mo> <m:mi>t</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:math> {f(t)/t} are not required.

title: Optimizing the Fractional Power in a Model with Stochastic PDE Constraints
abstract: Abstract We study an optimization problem with SPDE constraints, which has the peculiarity that the control parameter s is the s -th power of the diffusion operator in the state equation. Well-posedness of the state equation and differentiability properties with respect to the fractional parameter s are established. We show that under certain conditions on the noise, optimality conditions for the control problem can be established.

title: Optimal Design Problems for the First p-Fractional Eigenvalue with Mixed Boundary Conditions
authors: Juli√°n Fern√°ndez Bonder; Julio D. Rossi; Juan F. Spedaletti
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we study an optimal shape design problem for the first eigenvalue of the fractional p -Laplacian with mixed boundary conditions. The optimization variable is the set where the Dirichlet condition is imposed (that is restricted to have measure equal to a prescribed quantity Œ±). We show existence of an optimal design and analyze the asymptotic behavior when the fractional parameter s converges to 1, and thus obtain asymptotic bounds that are independent of Œ±.

title: Solitary Waves and Vortices in Non-Abelian Gauge Theories with Matter
abstract: Abstract We consider a non-Abelian gauge theory in ‚Ñù 4 equipped with the Minkowski metric, which provides a model for the interaction between a bosonic matter field and a gauge field with gauge group S U(2). We prove the existence of solitary waves which are related to those found for the Klein-Gordon-Maxwell equations.

title: Steady States, Global Existence and Blow-up for Fourth-Order Semilinear Parabolic Equations of Cahn‚ÄìHilliard Type
abstract: Abstract Fourth-order semilinear parabolic equations of the Cahn-Hilliard-type u t + Œî 2 u = Œ≥u ¬± Œî(|u| p‚àí1 u) in Œ© √ó ‚Ñù + , (0.1) are considered in a smooth bounded domain Œ© ‚äÇ ‚Ñù N with Navier-type boundary conditions on ‚àÇŒ©, or Œ© = ‚Ñù N , where p > 1 and Œ≥ are given real parameters. The sign ‚Äú+‚Äù in the ‚Äúdiffusion term‚Äù on the right-hand side means the stable case, while ‚Äú‚àí‚Äù reflects the unstable (blow-up) one, with the simplest, so called limit, canonical model for Œ≥ = 0, u t + Œî 2 u = ¬±Œî(|u| p‚àí1 u) in ‚Ñù N √ó R + . (0.2) The following three main problems are studied: (i) for the unstable model (0.1), with the ‚àíŒî(|u| p‚àí1 u), existence and multiplicity of classic steady states in Œ© ‚äÇ ‚Ñù N and their global behaviour for large Œ≥ > 0; (ii) for the stable model (0.2), global existence of smooth solutions u(x, t) in ‚Ñù N √ó R + for bounded initial data u 0 (x) in the subcritical case ; and (iii) for the unstable model (0.2), a relation between finite time blow-up and structure of regular and singular steady states in the supercritical range. In particular, three distinct families of Type I and II blow-up patterns are introduced in the unstable case.

</m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>m</m:mi> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:mfrac> </m:mrow> </m:math> {\sigma>\frac{2(1-p)}{m-1}} . As a first outcome, we show that finite time blow-up solutions in self-similar form exist for <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>m</m:mi> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> {m+p>2} and œÉ in the considered range, a fact that is completely new: in the already studied reaction-diffusion equation without weights there is no finite time blow-up when <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo><</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> {p<1} . We moreover prove that, if the condition <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>m</m:mi> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> {m+p>2} is fulfilled, all the self-similar blow-up profiles are compactly supported and there exist two different interface behaviors for solutions of the equation, corresponding to two different interface equations. We classify the self-similar blow-up profiles having both types of interfaces and show that in some cases global blow-up occurs, and in some other cases finite time blow-up occurs only at space infinity . We also show that there is no self-similar solution if <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>m</m:mi> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo><</m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> {m+p<2} , while the critical range <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>m</m:mi> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> {m+p=2} with <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>œÉ</m:mi> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> {\sigma>2} is postponed to a different work due to significant technical differences.

title: Reversed Stein‚ÄìWeiss Inequalities with Poisson-Type Kernel and Qualitative Analysis of Extremal Functions
abstract: Abstract Through conformal map, isoperimetric inequalities are equivalent to the Hardy‚ÄìLittlewood‚ÄìSobolev (HLS) inequalities involved with the Poisson-type kernel on the upper half space. From the analytical point of view, we want to know whether there exists a reverse analogue for the Poisson-type kernel. In this work, we give an affirmative answer to this question. We first establish the reverse Stein‚ÄìWeiss inequality with the Poisson-type kernel, finding that the range of index ùëù, <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mi>q</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Ä≤</m:mo> </m:msup> </m:math> q^{\prime} appearing in the reverse inequality lies in the interval <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> (0,1) , which is perfectly consistent with the feature of the index for the classical reverse HLS and Stein‚ÄìWeiss inequalities. Then we give the existence and asymptotic behaviors of the extremal functions of this inequality. Furthermore, for the reverse HLS inequalities involving the Poisson-type kernel, we establish the regularity for the positive solutions to the corresponding Euler‚ÄìLagrange system and give the sufficient and necessary conditions of the existence of their solutions. Finally, in the conformal invariant index, we classify the extremal functions of the latter reverse inequality and compute the sharp constant. Our methods are based on the reversed version of the Hardy inequality in high dimension, Riesz rearrangement inequality and moving spheres.

We also give conditions under which nonnegative solutions of <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:msubsup> <m:mi mathvariant="script">‚Ñí</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>q</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mi>M</m:mi> </m:msubsup> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> {{\mathcal{L}}^{{M}}_{p,q}u=0} in <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ©</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àñ</m:mo> <m:mi>K</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:math> {\Omega\setminus K} , where K is a compact subset of Œ©, can be extended as a solution of the same equation in Œ©.

abstract: Abstract We study existence and convergence properties of least-energy symmetric solutions (l.e.s.s.) to the pure critical exponent problem <m:math <m:mi>N</m:mi> </m:msup> </m:math> {\mathbb{R}^{N}} or a smooth symmetric bounded domain, and <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:msubsup> <m:mi>D</m:mi> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mi>s</m:mi> </m:msubsup> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ©</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {D^{s}_{0}(\Omega)} is the homogeneous Sobolev space. Depending on the kind of symmetry considered, solutions can be sign-changing. We show that, up to a subsequence, a l.e.s.s. <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msub> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mi>s</m:mi> </m:msub> </m:math> {u_{s}} converges to a l.e.s.s. <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msub> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mi>t</m:mi> </m:msub> </m:math> {u_{t}} as s goes to any <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>t</m:mi> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> {t>0} . In bounded domains, this convergence can be characterized in terms of an homogeneous fractional norm of order <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>t</m:mi> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mi>Œµ</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:math> {t-\varepsilon} . A similar characterization is no longer possible in unbounded domains due to scaling invariance and an incompatibility with the functional spaces; to circumvent these difficulties, we use a suitable rescaling and characterize the convergence via cut-off functions. If t is an integer, then these results describe in a precise way the nonlocal-to-local transition. Finally, we also include a nonexistence result of nontrivial nonnegative solutions in a ball for any <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>s</m:mi> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> {s>1} .

title: Subharmonic Solutions of Indefinite Hamiltonian Systems via Rotation Numbers
abstract: Abstract We investigate the multiplicity of subharmonic solutions for indefinite planar Hamiltonian systems <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>J</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mi>z</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Ä≤</m:mo> </m:msup> </m:mrow> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚àá</m:mo> <m:mo>‚Å°</m:mo> <m:mi>H</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mi>t</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>z</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {Jz^{\prime}=\nabla H(t,z)} from a rotation number viewpoint. The class considered is such that the behaviour of its solutions near zero and infinity can be compared two suitable positively homogeneous systems. Our approach can be used to deal with the problems in absence of the sign assumption on <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mfrac> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚àÇ</m:mo> <m:mo>‚Å°</m:mo> <m:mi>H</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚àÇ</m:mo> <m:mo>‚Å°</m:mo> <m:mi>x</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mfrac> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mi>t</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>y</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {\frac{\partial H}{\partial x}(t,x,y)} , uniqueness and global continuability for the solutions of the associated Cauchy problems. These systems may also be resonant. By the use of an approach of rotation number, the phase-plane analysis of the spiral properties of large solutions and a recent version of Poincar√©‚ÄìBirkhoff theorem for Hamiltonian systems, we are able to extend previous multiplicity results of subharmonic solutions for asymptotically semilinear systems to indefinite planar Hamiltonian systems.

title: Radial Nonlinear Elliptic Problems with Singular or Vanishing Potentials
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we prove the existence of radial solutions for the nonlinear elliptic problem <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>div</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>A</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</m:mo> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚àá</m:mo> <m:mo>‚Å°</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>V</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</m:mo> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>K</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</m:mo> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>f</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true"> </m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mtext>in </m:mtext> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi> <m:mi>N</m:mi> </m:msup> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>,</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> -\mathrm{div}(A(\lvert x\rvert)\nabla u)+V(\lvert x\rvert)u=K(\lvert x\rvert)f% (u)\quad\text{in }\mathbb{R}^{N}, with suitable hypotheses on the radial potentials A , V , K . We first get compact embeddings of radial weighted Sobolev spaces into sums of weighted Lebesgue spaces, and then we apply standard variational techniques to get existence results.

title: Complete Classification of the Positive Solutions of Heat Equation with Super Critical Absorption
abstract: Abstract Let . We prove that any positive solution of (E) ‚àÇ t u ‚àí Œîu + u q = 0 in ‚Ñù N √ó (0, ‚àû) admits an initial trace which is a nonnegative Borel measure, outer regular with respect to the fine topology associated to the Bessel capacity in ‚Ñù N (q π = q/(q ‚àí 1)) and absolutely continuous with respect to this capacity. If ŒΩ is a nonnegative Borel measure in ‚Ñù N with the above properties we construct a positive solution u of (E) with initial trace ŒΩ and we prove that this solution is the unique œÉ-moderate solution of (E) with such an initial trace. Finally we prove that every positive solution of (E) is œÉ-moderate.

title: The Topology of a Subspace of the Legendrian Curves on a Closed Contact 3-Manifold
abstract: Abstract In this paper we study a subspace of the space of Legendrian loops and we show that the injection of this space into the full loop space is an S 1 -equivariant homotopy equivalence. This space can be also seen as the space of zero Maslov index Legendrian loops and it shows up as a suitable space of variations in contact form geometry.

On the one hand, we prove the existence of minimizer for the system with <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>L</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> {L}^{2} -subcritical growth ( <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>N</m:mi> <m:mo>‚â§</m:mo> <m:mn>3</m:mn> </m:math> N\le 3 ). On the other hand, we prove the existence results for different ranges of the coupling parameter <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>Œ≤</m:mi> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:math> \beta \gt 0 with <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>L</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> {L}^{2} -supercritical growth ( <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>N</m:mi> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mn>5</m:mn> </m:math> N=5 ). Our argument is based on the rearrangement techniques and the minimax construction.

title: Global existence of the two-dimensional axisymmetric Euler equations for the Chaplygin gas with large angular velocities
authors: Dongyi Wei; Zhifei Zhang; Wenbin Zhao
abstract: Abstract The Chaplygin gas model is both interesting and important in the theory of gas dynamics and conservation laws, all the characteristic families of which are linearly degenerate. Majda conjectured that the shock formation never happens for smooth data. In this article, we prove the conjecture for the two space dimensional axisymmetric case. Different from previous approaches to study wave equations with different speeds, we reformulate the problem in the Lagrangian coordinates and consider a single wave equation with variable coefficients. This not only gives a simpler proof but also enables us to treat the case with large angular velocities.

title: Existence of ground state solutions for critical quasilinear Schr√∂dinger equations with steep potential well
authors: Yan-Fang Xue; Xiao-Jing Zhong; Chun‚ÄêLei Tang
abstract: Abstract We study the existence of solutions for the quasilinear Schr√∂dinger equation with the critical exponent and steep potential well. By using a change of variables, the quasilinear equations are reduced to a semilinear one, whose associated functionals satisfy the geometric conditions of the Mountain Pass Theorem for suitable assumptions. The existence of a ground state solution is obtained, and its concentration behavior is also considered.

title: Varying Stoichiometric Exponents I: Classical Steady-States and Metasolutions
abstract: Abstract This paper characterizes the existence of classical solutions for a class of semilinear elliptic boundary value problems of logistic type whose stoichiometric coefficient is allowed to vary within the region where the reaction takes place. Most of the effort will be focused on the problem of the existence of metasolutions; large solutions extended by infinity that are the main candidates for describing the dynamics of the model in the absence of classical steady-states.

title: Ground States and Singular Ground States for Quasilinear Partial Differential Equations with Critical Exponent in the Perturbative Case
abstract: Abstract We study the structure of the family of radially symmetric ground states and singular ground states for certain elliptic partial differential equations with p- Laplacian. We use methods of Dynamical systems such as Melnikov functions, invariant manifolds, and exponential dichotomy.

title: Variational Eigenvalues of Degenerate Eigenvalue Problems for the Weighted p-Laplacian
abstract: Abstract We prove the existence of nondecreasing sequences of positive eigenvalues of the homogeneous degenerate quasilinear eigenvalue problem ‚àí div(a(x)|‚ñΩu| p-2 ‚ñΩu) = Œªb(x)|u| p-2 u, Œª > 0 subject to Dirichlet boundary conditions on a bounded domain . The diffusion coefficient a(x) is a function in L 1 loc (Œ©) and b(x) is a nontrivial function in L r (Œ©) (r depending on a, p and N) and may change sign. We use Ljusternik-Schnirelman theory, minimax theory and the theory of weighted Sobolev spaces to establish our results.

title: Vortices with Prescribed L<sup>2</sup>Norm in the Nonlinear Wave Equation
abstract: Abstract We prove the existence of rotating solitary waves (vortices) with enough largely prescribed L 2 norm for the nonlinear Klein-Gordon equation with nonnegative potential, which makes the equation suitable for physical models and guarantees the well-posedness of the corresponding Cauchy problem. This is done by finding nonnegative cylindrical solutions to the standing equation where x = (y, z) ‚àà ‚Ñù k √ó R N‚Äìk , N > k ‚â• 0 and Œº > 0 is the fundamental eigenvalue, namely, the Lagrange multiplier of the minimization problem (with infimum over a suitable subspace of H 1 (‚Ñù N )).

title: An Alternative Variational Principle for Geodesics of a Randers Metric
abstract: Abstract We present an alternative variational principle for the geodesics of a Randers metric. We define a functional I on the manifold of H 1,2 curves joining two points on a Randers manifold (M, F) defined by a Riemannian metric g and a differential form œâ. The functional I is of class C 2 , so it is more regular than the usual action functional, which is only of class C 1,1 . Moreover the critical points of the functional I are the geodesics for the Randers metric F reparameterized with Riemannian length g constant. Some global properties of the functional I are investigated. Finally some applications to the Fermat principle in stationary spacetimes will be presented.

title: Orbital Instability of Standing Waves for the Klein-Gordon-Zakharov System
abstract: Abstract This paper deals with the instability of the ground state solitary wave solution to the Klein-Gordon-Zakharov system in three space dimensions with c ‚â• 1, which is a model to describe the Langmuir turbulence in plasma. First we construct a suitable constrained variational problem and obtain the existence of the standing waves with ground state by using variational calculus and scaling argument. Then by defining invariant sets and applying some priori estimates, we prove the orbital instability of the ground state in the following sense: in each neighborhood of it, there exists a solution whose energy diverges in finite or infinite time.

title: Asymptotic Speed of Propagation for Fisher-Type Degenerate Reaction-Diffusion-Convection Equations
abstract: Abstract The paper deals with the initial value problem for the degenerate reaction-diffusion-convection equation u t + h(u)u x = (u m ) xx + f(u), x ‚àà ‚Ñù, t > 0, where h is continuous, m > 1, and f is of Fisher-type. By means of comparison type techniques, we prove that the equilibrium u ‚â° 1 is an attractor for all solutions with a continuous, bounded, non-negative initial condition u 0 (x) = u(x, 0) ‚â¢ 0. When u 0 is also compactly supported and satisfies 0 ‚â§ u 0 ‚â§ 1, the convergence is such that an asymptotic estimate of the interface can be obtained. The employed techniques involve the theory of travelling-wave solutions that we improve in this context. The assumptions on f and h guarantee that the threshold speed wavefront is not stationary and we show that the asymptotic speed of the interface equals this minimal speed.

title: Compactness
abstract: Abstract We establish , within the framework of the variational problem and the homology for contact forms defined in [3], partial compactness results for flow-lines originating at periodic orbits. These compactness results are stronger when the index of the dominating periodic orbit is even.

title: Eigenvalue Problems for a Cooperative System with a Large Parameter
abstract: Abstract We consider the principal eigenvalue of a cooperative system of elliptic boundary value problems as a parameter tends to infinity. The main aim is to introduce a new approach to deal with the limit problem by focusing on the resolvent operator corresponding to the system rather than the eigenvalue problem itself. This allows the consistent use of elementary properties of bilinear forms and the semi-groups they induce. At the same time we weaken assumptions in related work.

title: Anisotropic Variable Exponent (p(¬∑), q(¬∑))-Laplacian with Large Exponents
abstract: Abstract In this work we consider the following Dirichlet problem corresponding to the anisotropic (p(¬∑), q(¬∑))‚àíLaplacian operator with variable exponents and study the behaviour of the solutions as the exponents p(x, y), q(x, y) ‚Üí ‚àû uniformly in Œ© ‚äÇ ‚Ñù N+K . We denote by and similarly the gradients of u with respect to the first N variables (x variables) and with respect to the last K variables (y variables), respectively. We consider sequences of exponents p n (x, y), q n (x, y) going to infinity uniformly in Œ© and verifying suitable assumptions. We prove that u n , the solutions with p(x, y) = p n (x, y) q(x, y) = qn(x, y), converge uniformly in Œ©ÃÖ to some nontrivial limit, u ‚àû , as an ‚Üí ‚àû. We determine the limit equation verified by u ‚àû as well as some properties of this limit. Finally, we focus on the case f = 0 (with nontrivial Dirichlet boundary conditions, u = g ‚â¢ 0 on ‚àÇŒ©) and show uniqueness for the limit problem.

title: One-Signed Harmonic Solutions and Sign-Changing Subharmonic Solutions to Scalar Second Order Differential Equations
abstract: Abstract Using a recent modified version of the Poincar√©-Birkhoff fixed point theorem [19], we study the existence of one-signed T-periodic solutions and sign-changing subharmonic solutions to the second order scalar ODE u‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ + f (t, u) = 0, being f : ‚Ñù √ó ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù a continuous function T-periodic in the first variable and such that f (t, 0) ‚â° 0. Partial extensions of the results to a general planar Hamiltonian systems are given, as well.

title: Existence Results for the Prescribed Webster Scalar Curvature on Higher Dimensional CR Manifolds
abstract: Abstract This paper is about prescribing the Webster scalar curvature on a compact CR manifold of dimension 2n+1 ‚â• 5, which is locally CR equivalent to the standard CR unit sphere S 2n+1 . The associated variational problem being noncompact we approach this issue with techniques from the critical points at infinity theory, combined with topological tools. Our existence results are based on a generalized Bahri-Coron type criteria. We also give an upper bound on the Morse index of the obtained solutions.

title: Some Results on Weak KAM Theory for Time-periodic Tonelli Lagrangian Systems
abstract: Abstract This paper contributes several results on weak KAM theory for time-periodic Tonelli Lagrangian systems. Wang and Yan [Commun. Math. Phys. 309 (2012), 663-691] introduced a new kind of Lax-Oleinik type operator associated with any time-periodic Tonelli Lagrangian. Firstly, using the new operator we give an equivalent definition of the backward weak KAM solution. Then we prove a result on the asymptotic behavior of the new operators with an arbitrary continuous function as initial condition, by taking advantage of the definition mentioned above. Finally, for a specific class of time-periodic Tonelli Lagrangians, we discuss the rate of convergence of the new operators.

title: Location of Bifurcation Points for a Reaction-Diffusion System with Neumann-Signorini Conditions
abstract: Abstract We consider a reaction-diffusion system of activator-inhibitor or substrate-depletion type in one space dimension which is subject to diffusion-driven instability. We determine the change of bifurcation when a pure Neumann condition is supplemented with a Signorini condition. We show that this change differs essentially from the known case when also Dirichlet conditions are assumed.

title: A Biharmonic Equation in ‚Ñú<sup>4</sup> Involving Nonlinearities with Subcritical Exponential Growth
abstract: Abstract In this paper we consider a biharmonic equation of the form Œî 2 u+V(x)u = f (u) in the whole four-dimensional space ‚Ñú 4 . Assuming that the potential V satisfies some symmetry conditions and is bounded away from zero and that the nonlinearity f is odd and has subcritical exponential growth (in the sense of an Adams‚Äô type inequality), we prove a multiplicity result. More precisely we prove the existence of infinitely many nonradial sign-changing solutions and infinitely many radial solutions in H 2 (‚Ñú 4 ). The main difficulty is the lack of compactness due to the unboundedness of the domain ‚Ñú 4 and in this respect the symmetries of the problem play an important role.

title: Global Existence Results for Near Triangular Nonlinear Parabolic Systems
abstract: Abstract We study the global existence and regularity of weak solutions to strongly coupled parabolic systems whose diffusion matrices are almost triangular.

title: The Grand Sobolev Homeomorphisms and Their Measurability Properties
authors: Luigi D‚ÄôOnofrio; Carlo Sbordone; Roberta Schiattarella
abstract: Abstract We study the validity of the condition (N) of Lusin for homeomorphisms under minimal assumptions on the integrability of Df. It turns out that the role of grand Sobolev spaces W 1,n) and W b 1,n) is crucial. A discussion of bi-Sobolev maps in the plane and their connections with degenerate elliptic PDEs is provided.

title: Blow up Points and the Morse Indices of Solutions to the Liouville Equation in Two-Dimension
abstract: Abstract We consider the Liouville equation ‚àíŒîu = Œªeu in Œ©, u =0 on‚àÇŒ©, on a smooth bounded domain Œ© in ‚Ñù 2 , where Œª > 0 is a parameter. Let {u n } be an m-point blowing up solution sequence of the problem for Œª = Œªn ‚Üì 0, which satisfies for m ‚àà‚Ñï. We prove that the number of blow up points m is less than or equal to the Morse index of u n for n sufficiently large. As a corollary, we show that if a solution u n of Morse index one has the property that , then the number of blow up points of the sequence is exactly one. Note that in the last result, we do not need any geometrical assumption such as the convexity of the domain.

title: Nontrivial Solutions for Potential Systems Involving the Mean Curvature Operator in Minkowski Space

The solvability of a general non-potential system is also established.

title: High-Order Melnikov Method for Time-Periodic Equations
abstract: Abstract This paper discusses a high-order Melnikov method for periodically perturbed equations. We introduce a new method to compute <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:msub> <m:mi>M</m:mi> <m:mi>k</m:mi> </m:msub> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:msub> <m:mi>t</m:mi> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:msub> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {M_{k}(t_{0})} for all <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>k</m:mi> <m:mo>‚â•</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> {k\geq 0} , among which <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:msub> <m:mi>M</m:mi> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:msub> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:msub> <m:mi>t</m:mi> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:msub> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {M_{0}(t_{0})} is the traditional Melnikov function, and <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:msub> <m:mi>M</m:mi> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:msub> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:msub> <m:mi>t</m:mi> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:msub> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:msub> <m:mi>M</m:mi> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:msub> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:msub> <m:mi>t</m:mi> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:msub> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mpadded width="+1.7pt"> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">‚Ä¶</m:mi> </m:mpadded> </m:mrow> </m:math> {M_{1}(t_{0}),M_{2}(t_{0}),\ldots\,} are its high-order correspondences. We prove that, for all <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>k</m:mi> <m:mo>‚â•</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> {k\geq 0} , <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:msub> <m:mi>M</m:mi> <m:mi>k</m:mi> </m:msub> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:msub> <m:mi>t</m:mi> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:msub> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {M_{k}(t_{0})} is a sum of certain multiple integrals, the integrand of which we can explicitly compute. In particular, we obtain explicit integral formulas for <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:msub> <m:mi>M</m:mi> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:msub> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:msub> <m:mi>t</m:mi> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:msub> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {M_{0}(t_{0})} and <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:msub> <m:mi>M</m:mi> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:msub> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:msub> <m:mi>t</m:mi> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:msub> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {M_{1}(t_{0})} . We also study a concrete equation for which the explicit formula of <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:msub> <m:mi>M</m:mi> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:msub> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:msub> <m:mi>t</m:mi> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:msub> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {M_{1}(t_{0})} is used to prove the existence of a transversal homoclinic intersection in the case of <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:msub> <m:mi>M</m:mi> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:msub> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:msub> <m:mi>t</m:mi> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:msub> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>‚â°</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> {M_{0}(t_{0})\equiv 0} .

title: On a Class of Quasilinear Elliptic Equations with Degenerate Coerciveness and Measure Data
abstract: Abstract We study the existence of measure-valued solutions for a class of degenerate elliptic equations with measure data. The notion of solution is natural, since it is obtained by a regularization procedure which also relies on a standard approximation of the datum Œº. We provide partial uniqueness results and qualitative properties of the constructed solutions concerning, in particular, the structure of their diffuse part with respect to the harmonic-capacity.

title: Boundedness of Solutions to a Parabolic-Elliptic Keller‚ÄìSegel Equation in ‚Ñù<sup>2</sup> with Critical Mass
abstract: Abstract We consider the Cauchy problem for a parabolic-elliptic system in <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:msup> </m:math> {\mathbb{R}^{2}} , called the parabolic-elliptic Keller‚ÄìSegel equation, which appears in various fields in biology and physics. In the critical mass case where the total mass of the initial data is <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mn>8</m:mn> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>œÄ</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:math> {8\pi} , the unboundedness of nonnegative solutions to the Cauchy problem was shown by Blanchet, Carrillo and Masmoudi [7] under some conditions on the initial data, on the other hand, conditions for boundedness were given by Blanchet, Carlen and Carrillo [6] and L√≥pez-G√≥mez, Nagai and Yamada [23]. In this paper, we investigate further the boundedness of nonnegative solutions.
