title: Fractional Choquard Equations with Confining Potential With or Without Subcritical Perturbations
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we consider fractional Choquard equations with confining potentials. First, we show that they admit a positive ground state and infinitely many bound states. Then we prove the existence of two signed solutions when a superlinear and subcritical perturbation is added; in this case, the main feature is that such a perturbation does not satisfy the usual Ambrosetti‚ÄìRabinowitz condition.

title: Limit Configurations of Schr√∂dinger Systems Versus Optimal Partition for the Principal Eigenvalue of Elliptic Systems
abstract: Abstract We study a Schr√∂dinger system of four equations with linear coupling functions and nonlinear couplings, including the case that the corresponding elliptic operators are indefinite. For any given nonlinear coupling <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>Œ≤</m:mi> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> {\beta>0} , we first use minimizing sequences on a normalized set to obtain a minimizer, which implies the existence of positive solutions for some linear coupling constants <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:msub> <m:mi>Œº</m:mi> <m:mi>Œ≤</m:mi> </m:msub> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:msub> <m:mi>ŒΩ</m:mi> <m:mi>Œ≤</m:mi> </m:msub> </m:mrow> </m:math> {\mu_{\beta},\nu_{\beta}} by Lagrange multiplier rules. Then, as <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>Œ≤</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Üí</m:mo> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">‚àû</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:math> {\beta\to\infty} , we prove that the limit configurations to the competing system are segregated in two groups, develop a variant of Almgren‚Äôs monotonicity formula to reveal the Lipschitz continuity of the limit profiles and establish a kind of local Pohozaev identity to obtain the extremality conditions. Finally, we study the relation between the limit profiles and the optimal partition for principal eigenvalue of the elliptic system and obtain an optimal partition for principal eigenvalues of elliptic systems.

title: A Morse Lemma for Degenerate Critical Points of Solutions of Nonlinear Equations in ‚Ñù<sup>2</sup>
abstract: Abstract In this paper we prove a Morse Lemma for degenerate critical points of a function u which satisfies <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œî</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>f</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true"> </m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mtext>in </m:mtext> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:msub> <m:mi>B</m:mi> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:msub> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>,</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> -\Delta u=f(u)\quad\text{in }B_{1}, where <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àà</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mi>C</m:mi> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:msup> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:msub> <m:mi>B</m:mi> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:msub> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {u\in C^{2}(B_{1})} , <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msub> <m:mi>B</m:mi> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:msub> </m:math> {B_{1}} is the unit ball of <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:msup> </m:math> {\mathbb{R}^{2}} and f is a smooth nonlinearity. Other results on the nondegeneracy of the critical points and the shape of the level sets are proved.

title: Global Existence for some Cross Diffusion Systems with Equal Cross Diffusion/Reaction Rates
abstract: Abstract We consider some cross diffusion systems which is inspired by models in mathematical biology/ecology, in particular the Shigesada‚ÄìKawasaki‚ÄìTeramoto (SKT) model in population biology. We establish the global existence of strong solutions to systems for multiple species having equal either diffusion or reaction rates. The systems are given on bounded domains of arbitrary dimension.

title: Multiple Solutions for Superlinear Fractional Problems via Theorems of Mixed Type
abstract: In this paper we investigate the existence of multiple solutions for the following two fractional problems \begin{equation*} \left\{\begin{array}{ll} (-\Delta_{\Omega})^{s} u-\lambda u= f(x, u) &\mbox{in} \Omega \\ u=0 &\mbox{in} \partial \Omega \end{array} \right. \end{equation*} and \begin{equation*} \left\{\begin{array}{ll} (-\Delta_{\mathbb{R}^{N}})^{s} u-\lambda u= f(x, u) &\mbox{in} \Omega \\ u=0 &\mbox{in} \mathbb{R}^{N}\setminus \Omega, \end{array} \right. \end{equation*} where $s\in (0,1)$, $N>2s$, $\Omega$ is a smooth bounded domain of $\mathbb{R}^{N}$, and $f:\bar{\Omega}\times \mathbb{R}\rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is a superlinear continuous function which does not satisfy the well-known Ambrosetti-Rabinowitz condition. Here $(-\Delta_{\Omega})^{s}$ is the spectral Laplacian and $(-\Delta_{\mathbb{R}^{N}})^{s}$ is the fractional Laplacian in $\mathbb{R}^{N}$. By applying variational theorems of mixed type due to Marino and Saccon and Linking Theorem, we prove the existence of multiple solutions for the above problems.

title: Sign-Changing Solutions for the One-Dimensional Non-Local sinh-Poisson Equation
authors: Azahara DelaTorre; Gabriele Mancini; Angela Pistoia
abstract: Abstract We study the existence of sign-changing solutions for a non-local version of the sinh-Poisson equation on a bounded one-dimensional interval I , under Dirichlet conditions in the exterior of I . This model is strictly related to the mathematical description of galvanic corrosion phenomena for simple electrochemical systems. By means of the finite-dimensional Lyapunov‚ÄìSchmidt reduction method, we construct bubbling families of solutions developing an arbitrarily prescribed number sign-alternating peaks. With a careful analysis of the limit profile of the solutions, we also show that the number of nodal regions coincides with the number of blow-up points.

title: Solutions with Prescribed Local Blow-up Surface for the Nonlinear Wave Equation
authors: Thierry Cazenave; Yvan Martel; Lifeng Zhao
abstract: We prove that any sufficiently differentiable space-like hypersurface of ${\mathbb R}^{1+N} $ coincides locally around any of its points with the blow-up surface of a finite-energy solution of the focusing nonlinear wave equation $\partial_{tt} u - \Delta u=|u|^{p-1} u$ on ${\mathbb R} \times {\mathbb R} ^N$, for any $1\leq N\leq 4$ and $1 < p \le \frac {N+2} {N-2}$. We follow the strategy developed in our previous work [arXiv 1812.03949] on the construction of solutions of the nonlinear wave equation blowing up at any prescribed compact set. Here to prove blowup on a local space-like hypersurface, we first apply a change of variable to reduce the problem to blowup on a small ball at $t=0$ for a transformed equation. The construction of an appropriate approximate solution is then combined with an energy method for the existence of a solution of the transformed problem that blows up at $t=0$. To obtain a finite-energy solution of the original problem from trace arguments, we need to work with $H^2\times H^1$ solutions for the transformed problem.

title: On a Class of Reaction-Diffusion Equations with Aggregation
authors: Li Chen; Laurent Desvillettes; Evangelos Latos
abstract: Abstract In this paper, global-in-time existence and blow-up results are shown for a reaction-diffusion equation appearing in the theory of aggregation phenomena (including chemotaxis). Properties of the corresponding steady-state problem are also presented. Moreover, the stability around constant equilibria and the non-existence of nonconstant solutions are studied in certain cases.

title: On the Profile of Globally and Locally Minimizing Solutions of the Spatially Inhomogeneous Allen‚ÄìCahn and Fisher‚ÄìKPP Equations

title: Traveling Wave Solutions to the Burgers-Œ±Œ≤ Equations
On the Existence of Boundary Blow-up Solutions for a General Class of Quasilinear Elliptic Systems
authors: Sonia Ben Othman; Rym Chemmam; Paul Sauvy
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we investigate the following quasilinear elliptic system (P) with explosive boundary conditions: Œî p u = f 1 (x, u, v) in Œ©; u| ‚àÇŒ© = +‚àû, u >0 in Œ©, Œî q v = f 2 (x, u, v) in Œ©; v| ‚àÇŒ© = +‚àû, v >0 in Œ©, where Œ© is a smooth bounded domain of ‚Ñù N , N ‚â• 2, 1 < p, q < +‚àû and f 1 , f 2 are two Carath√©odory functions in Œ© √ó (‚Ñù + * √ó ‚àó ‚Ñù + *). Under rather general conditions on f 1 and f 2 and assuming the existence of a sub and supersolutions pair, we prove the existence of a large solution to (P) by a fixed point approach. Then, we apply this result considering particular systems arising in Biology.

title: Conjectures and Suggestions for Directions in Pursuing Research in Nonlinear Analysis
abstract: Abstract In this paper, which is a mixture of original and expository ideas, the author shares some sketches of his research ideas and projects on certain important areas in Nonlinear Analysis. In addition to stating some open conjectures and suggestions for directions, the paper also contains an erratum to a previously published article.

title: Positive and Nodal Solutions of Nonlinear Schr√∂dinger Equations in a Saturable Medium
abstract: Abstract We consider the nonlinear Schr√∂dinger equation ‚àíŒîu + V(x)u = f (x, u), x ‚àà ‚Ñù N , where V is invariant under an orthogonal involution and converges to a positive constant as |x| ‚Üí +‚àû and the nonlinearity f is asymptotically linear at infinity. Existence of a positive solution, as well as some results on the existence of a class of sign-changing solutions is presented. The new idea is to use the projection on the Pohozaev manifold associated with the problem at infinity in order to show that a min-max energy level is in the appropriate range for compactness.

title: A Minimum Problem with Free Boundary for the p(x)‚àíLaplace Operator
abstract: Abstract In this paper we consider the problem of minimizing the functional We prove Lipschitz continuity for each minimizer u and establish the nondegeneracy at the free boundary (‚àÇ[u > 0]) ‚à© Œ© and the locally uniform positive density of the sets [u > 0] and [u = 0]. In particular we obtain that the Lebesgue measure of the free boundary is zero.

title: On the Necessity of theWiener Condition for Singular Parabolic Equations with Non-standard Growth
abstract: Abstract We investigate the continuity of solutions for general nonlinear parabolic equations with non-standard growth near a nonsmooth boundary of a cylindrical domain. We prove the Wiener Criterion for the regularity of a boundary point.

title: Positive Answer to Berestycki‚Äôs Open Problem on the Unit Ball
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we establish a unilateral global bifurcation result from intervals for a class of semilinear problems on the unit ball. By applying the above result, we obtain the spectrum of a class of half-linear problems on the unit ball. Our results partially give a positive answer to the open problem proposed by Berestycki.

title: Heteroclinic Connections for the Swift-Hohenberg Equation with Multi-wells Potentials
abstract: Abstract Given a C 2 nonnegative potential F with a discrete set of zeros we consider the existence of heteroclinics connecting two arbitrary zeros of F for the Swift-Hohenberg equation, i.e. u ∫ ∫‚àí Œ≤u ∫ + F π (u) = 0, for Œ≤ ‚â§ 0. The emphasis is on the case where F has more than two zeros. We prove that when F π has a sign near the zeros of F, |Œ≤| is sufficiently small in a variational sense, and then given any two different zeros z ‚Äì and z + , there exists a solution to the Swift-Hohenberg equation with boundary values . We also consider heteroclinics constrained in a strip of the form {l < u(x) < r}, and consider some local conditions on F which produce heteroclinics regardless of the behavior of F outside [l, r].

title: New Asymptotic Stability and Uniqueness Results on Periodic Solutions of Second Order Differential Equations Using Degree Theory
abstract: Abstract We present new criteria for uniqueness and asymptotic stability of periodic solutions of a second order differential equation based on topological degree theory. As an application, we will study some well known equations and some illustrative examples.

title: An Obstacle Problem in a Plane Domain with two Solutions
authors: Giovany M. Figueiredo; Marcelo F. Furtado; Marcelo Montenegro
abstract: Abstract We prove the existence of two nontrivial solutions for the variational inequality ‚à´ Œ© ‚àáu‚àá(v ‚àí u) ‚â• ‚à´ Œ© f(u)(v ‚àí u) for every v belonging to some convex set, where Œ© ‚äÇ ‚Ñù 2 . The function f has critical exponential growth, in the sense that it behaves like exp(Œ± 0 s 2 ) as |s| ‚Üí ‚àû, for some Œ± 0 > 0. We use variational methods for lower semicontinuous functionals.

title: Infinitely Many Spiky Solutions for a H√©non Type Biharmonic Equation with Critical Growth
authors: Jianghao Hao; Yajing Zhang; Xinfu Chen
abstract: Abstract Following the constructive method of Wei and Yan [29], with new ingredients to take care of high-space dimensions, we prove the existence of infinitely many solutions of the nonlinear biharmonic equation in the unit ball of ‚Ñù n (n ‚â• 6, Œ± > 0) with the Navier conditions v = Œîv = 0 on the boundary.

title: Stable Transition Layers to Singularly Perturbed Spatially Inhomogeneous Allen-Cahn Equation
authors: Arnaldo Simal do Nascimento; Maicon S√¥nego
abstract: Abstract We use the variational concept of Œì-convergence to prove existence, stability and exhibit the geometric structure of four families of stationary solutions to the singularly perturbed parabolic equation u t = Œµ 2 Œîu + u[a 2 (x) ‚àí u 2 ], for (t, x) ‚àà ‚Ñù + √ó Œ©, where Œ© ‚äÇ ‚Ñù 2 and a is positive, supplied with no-flux boundary condition. Let Œ≥ ‚äÇ Œ© be a smooth simple closed curve and N(Œ≥) a narrow tubular neighborhood of Œ≥. Roughly speaking, the sufficient condition found for existence of such solutions relates the geometric profile of the function a in N(Œ≥) to the signed curvature of Œ≥ .

title: The p-Laplace Equation in Domains with Multiple Crack Section via Pencil Operators
abstract: Abstract The p-Laplace equation ‚àá ¬∑ (|‚àáu| p‚àí2 ‚àáu) = 0, where p > 2, in a bounded domain Œ© ‚äÇ ‚Ñù 2 , with inhomogeneous Dirichlet conditions on the smooth boundary ‚àÇŒ© is considered. In addition, there is a finite collection of curves Œì = Œì 1 ‚à™ ... ‚à™ Œì m ‚äÇ Œ©, on which we assume homogeneous Dirichlet conditions u = 0, modeling a multiple crack formation, focusing at the origin 0 ‚àà Œ©. This makes the above quasilinear elliptic problem overdetermined. Possible types of the behaviour of solution u(x, y) at the tip 0 of such admissible multiple cracks, being a ‚Äúsingularity‚Äù point, are described, on the basis of blow-up scaling techniques and a ‚Äúnonlinear eigenvalue problem‚Äù via spectral theory of pencils of non self-adjoint operators. Specially interesting is the application of those techniques to non-linear problems as the one considered here. To do so we introduce a very novel change of variable compared with the classical one introduced by Kondratiev for the analysis of non-smooth domains, such as domains with corner points, edges, etc, studying the behaviour of the solutions at those problematic points. Typical types of admissible cracks are shown to be governed by nodal sets of a countable family of nonlinear eigenfunctions, which are obtained via branching from harmonic polynomials that occur for p = 2. Using a combination of analytic and numerical methods, saddle-node bifurcations in p are shown to occur for those nonlinear eigenvalues/ eigenfunctions.

title: Dynamics of Periodic Second-Order Equations Between an Ordered Pair of Lower and Upper Solutions
abstract: Abstract We consider periodic second-order equations having an ordered pair of lower and upper solutions and show the existence of asymptotic trajectories heading towards the maximal and minimal periodic solutions which lie between them.

title: A Note on Closed Geodesics for a Class of Non-Compact Riemannian Manifolds
abstract: This paper is concerned with the existence of closed geodesics on a non‚Äìcompact manifold M . There are very few papers on such a problem, see [3, 13, 14]. In particular, Tanaka deals with the manifod M = R√óS , endowed with a metric g(s, Œæ) = g0(Œæ) + h(s, Œæ), where g0 is the standard product metric on R √ó S N . Under the assumption that h(s, Œæ) ‚Üí 0 as |s| ‚Üí ‚àû, he proves the existence of a closed geodesic, found as a critical point of the energy functional

title: Existence of a Closed Geodesic on Non-compact Riemannian Manifolds with Boundary
authors: Rossella Bartolo; Anna Germinario; Miguel S√°nchez
abstract: Abstract A new result about the existence of a closed geodesic on a Riemannian manifold with boundary is given. A detailed comparison with previous results is carried out.

title: On Variational Inequalities Driven by Elliptic Operators Not in Divergence Form
abstract: Abstract In this paper we study semilinear variational inequalities driven by an elliptic operator not in divergence form modeled by where Œ© is a bounded domain of RN, N ‚â• 3, with smooth boundary, A is the elliptic operator, not in divergence form, given by Here a ij , a i , i,j = 1,...,N , and a 0 satisfy suitable regularity conditions, while 1 < s < 4/(N ‚àí 2) and the obstacle œà is a function sufficiently smooth. Even if this problem is not variational in nature, we will prove the existence of non-trivial non-negative solutions for it, performing a variational approach combined with a penalization technique. This kind of approach seems to be new for problems of this type. We also prove a C 1,Œ± -regularity result for the solutions of our problem.

title: œâ-Index Theory and Linear Stability of Elliptic Lagrangian Solutions of the Classical Three-Body Problem
abstract: Abstract It is well known that the linear stability of Lagrangian elliptic equilateral triangle homographic solutions in the classical planar three-body problem depends on the mass parameter Œ≤ = 27(m 1 m 2 + m 2 m 3 + m 3 m 1 )/(m 1 + m 2 + m 3 ) 2 ‚àà [0, 9] and the eccentricity ‚ÑØ ‚àà [0, 1). We are not aware of any existing analytical method which relates the linear stability of these solutions to these two parameters directly in the full rectangle [0, 9] √ó [0, 1), besides perturbation methods for ‚ÑØ > 0 small enough, blow-up techniques for e sufficiently close to 1, and numerical studies. In the recent paper [5], X. Hu, S. Sun and the author introduced a new rigorous analytical method to study the linear stability of these solutions in terms of the two parameters in the full (Œ≤, ‚ÑØ) range [0, 9] √ó [0, 1) via the œâ-index theory of symplectic paths for œâ belonging to the unit circle of the complex plane, and the theory of linear operators. This is an expository article on [5]. In Section 1 of this paper we give a brief review on the history of this stability problem, and describe recent results obtained in [5]. Then in Section 2, after reviewing the œâ-index theory in [15], the œâ-index decreasing property of the elliptic Lagragian solutions in Œ≤ for fixed ‚ÑØ ‚àà [0, 1) proved in [5] is introduced, then the existence of three curves located from left to right in the parameter rectangle [0, 9] √ó [0, 1) is explained. Among these three curves, two are precisely the ‚àí1 degeneracy curves and the third one is the left boundary curve of the hyperbolic subregion in [0, 9] √ó [0, 1). Then in Section 3, it is explained why the linear stability pattern of such an elliptic Lagrangian solution q Œ≤,‚ÑØ changes if and only if the parameter (Œ≤, ‚ÑØ) passes through one of these three curves. Some open problems on related topics are suggested at the end of this paper.

title: On the Decay in Time of Solutions of the Generalized Regularized Boussinesq System
abstract: Abstract We are interested in dispersive properties of the Boussinesq system for small initial data. We prove that, for a suficiently high order nonlinearity, the solution of the Boussinesq system exists for all time and tends to zero as the time tends to infinity.

title: Nonlinear Schr√∂dinger Equations with Sign-Changing Potential
abstract: possesses at least one non-trivial solution pair (u, v) for Œª > 0 large enough, where f (x, t), g(x, t) are continuous functions on ‚ÑùN √ó ‚Ñù and super-linear at t = 0 as well as at t = +‚àû, V(x) is allowed to be sign-changing. We mention that we do not assume that f or g satisfies the Ambrosetti-Rabinowitz condition.

title: Multiplicity Results for a Class of Asymptotically Linear Elliptic Problems With Resonance and Applications to Problems With Measure Data
abstract: Abstract We study existence and multiplicity results for solutions of elliptic problems of the type -Œîu = g(x; u) in a bounded domain Œ© with Dirichlet boundary conditions. The function g(x; s) is asymptotically linear as |s| ‚Üí +‚àû. Also resonant situations are allowed. We also prove some perturbation results for Dirichlet problems of the type -Œîu = g ∆ê (x, u) where g Œµ (x, s) ‚Üí g(x, s) as Œµ ‚Üí 0. The previous results find an application in the study of Dirichlet problems of the type -Œîu = g(x, u)+Œº where Œº is a Radon measure. To properly set the above mentioned problems in a variational framework we also study existence and properties of critical points of a class of abstract nonsmooth functional defined on Banach spaces and extend to this nonsmooth framework some classical linking theorems.

title: Coexistence States for Cyclic 3-Dimensional Systems
abstract: Abstract We find coexistence states for systems in three dimensions with cyclic dynamic in the boundary of ‚Ñù + 3 . This problem had been already studied for competitive systems. In this paper we consider any interaction. This extension seems to be meaningful since the cyclic dynamic on the boundary can appear in natural way in many interactions.

title: On Generalized and Viscosity Solutions of Nonlinear Elliptic Equations
abstract: Abstract There are many notions of solutions of nonlinear elliptic partial differential equations. This paper is concerned with solutions which are obtained as suprema (or infima) of so-called subfunctions (superfunctions) or viscosity subsolutions (viscosity supersolutions). The paper also explores the relationship of these (generalized) solutions of differential inequalities and provides a relevant example for which existence questions have been studied using these concepts.

title: Semilinear Integrodifferential Problems With Non-Symmetric Kernels Via Mountain-Pass Techniques
abstract: Abstract Integrodifferential equations with non-symmetric kernels are considered. The existence of a non-negative solution is stated through an iterative scheme and a mountain-pass technique.

title: Concentration Phenomena in a Biharmonic Equation Involving the Critical Sobolev Exponent
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we consider the problem Œî 2 u = |u| 8/(n-4) u + Œµf(x, u) in Œ©, u = Œîu = 0 on ‚àÇŒ©, where Œ© is a bounded and smooth domain in ‚Ñù n , n ‚â• 6, Œµ is a small positive parameter, and f is a smooth function. Our main purpose is to construct families of solutions which concentrate around some well defined points depending on f.

title: A Note on Nonlinear Schr√∂dinger Systems: Existence of A-symmetric Solutions
abstract: Abstract The paper contains some results concerning the existence of a-symmetric solutions to a class of autonomous nonlinear Schr√∂dinger systems, coupled through a small parameter.

title: Solutions of Multiparameter Systems of Elliptic Differential Equations
abstract: Abstract In this article we study bifurcations of weak solutions of the following multiparameter variational system of elliptic differential equations: We formulate necessary and sufficient conditions for the existence of bifurcation points and global bifurcation points of weak solutions of this system.

title: Multi-Bump Standing Waves for Nonlinear Schr√∂dinger Equations with a General Nonlinearity: The Topological Effect of Potential Wells
abstract: Abstract In this article, we are interested in multi-bump solutions of the singularly perturbed problem <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mi>Œµ</m:mi> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:msup> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œî</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>v</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>V</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>v</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>f</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mi>v</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true"> </m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mtext>in </m:mtext> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi> <m:mi>N</m:mi> </m:msup> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>.</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> -\varepsilon^{2}\Delta v+V(x)v=f(v)\quad\text{in }\mathbb{R}^{N}. Extending previous results, we prove the existence of multi-bump solutions for an optimal class of nonlinearities f satisfying the Berestycki‚ÄìLions conditions and, notably, also for more general classes of potential wells than those previously studied. We devise two novel topological arguments to deal with general classes of potential wells. Our results prove the existence of multi-bump solutions in which the centers of bumps converge toward potential wells as <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>Œµ</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Üí</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> {\varepsilon\rightarrow 0} . Examples of potential wells include the following: the union of two compact smooth submanifolds of <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi> <m:mi>N</m:mi> </m:msup> </m:math> {\mathbb{R}^{N}} where these two submanifolds meet at the origin and an embedded topological submanifold of <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi> <m:mi>N</m:mi> </m:msup> </m:math> {\mathbb{R}^{N}} .

title: Existence of Ground States of Fractional Schr√∂dinger Equations
abstract: Abstract We consider ground states of the nonlinear fractional Schr√∂dinger equation with potentials <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œî</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mi>s</m:mi> </m:msup> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>V</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>f</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo rspace="12.5pt">,</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>s</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àà</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>,</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> (-\Delta)^{s}u+V(x)u=f(x,u),\quad s\in(0,1), on the whole space <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi> <m:mi>N</m:mi> </m:msup> </m:math> {\mathbb{R}^{N}} , where V is a periodic non-negative nontrivial function on <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi> <m:mi>N</m:mi> </m:msup> </m:math> {\mathbb{R}^{N}} and the nonlinear term f has some proper growth on u . Under uniform bounded assumptions about V , we can show the existence of a ground state. We extend the result of Li, Wang, and Zeng to the fractional case.

title: Periodic Bifurcation For Semilinear Differential Equations With Lipschitzian Perturbations in Banach Spaces
authors: Mikhail Kamenskiƒ≠; Oleg Makarenkovy; Paolo Nistriz
abstract: Abstract Let A : D(A) ‚Üí E, D(A) ‚äÇ E; be an infinitesimal generator either of an analytic compact semigroup or of a contractive C 0 -semigroup of linear operators acting in a Banach space E. In this paper we give both necessary and sufficient conditions for bifurcation of T- periodic solutions for the equation ·∫ã = Ax + f(t, x) + Œµg(t, x, Œµ) from a k-parameterized family of T-periodic solutions of the unperturbed equation corresponding to Œµ = 0. We show that by means of a suitable modification of the classical Mel‚Äônikov approach we can construct a bifurcation function and to formulate the conditions for the existence of bifurcation in terms of the topological index of the bifurcation function. To do this, since the perturbation term g is only Lipschitzian we need to extend the classical Lyapunov- Schmidt reduction to the present nonsmooth case.

title: Corrigendum to Existence and Regularity Results for Anisotropic Elliptic Problems
Multiplicity of Solutions For p-Laplacian Equations Which Need Not be Coercive
authors: Michael Œï. Filippakis; Nikolaos S. Papageorgiou
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we consider nonlinear Dirichlet problem driven by the p-Laplacian differential operator. Using variational methods based on the critical point theory and truncation techniques, we prove the existence of at least three nontrivial smooth solutions. The hypotheses on the nonlinearity incorporate in our framework of analysis both coercive and noncoercive problems. For the semilinear problem (p = 2), using Morse theory, we show the existence of four nontrivial smooth solutions.

title: Critical Boundary Source Exponent in a Doubly Degenerate Parabolic Equation
abstract: Abstract This paper deals with a doubly degenerate parabolic equation with absorption (u n ) t = (|u x | m-1 u x ) x - Œ∑u p in (0, 1) √ó (0, T) subject to the boundary source (|u x | m-1 u x )(1, t) = u q (1, t). The critical boundary source exponent q c is determined under different dominations to identify global and non-global solutions. A complete classification for all of the four nonlinear exponents m, n, p, q with the coefficient Œ∑ draws a very clear picture of interactions among the multi-nonlinearities. It is shown that q c depends on the absorption exponent p if and only if p > n. It is found as well that q c is related to small m only: q c relies on m if and only if m < p when p > n, also q c relies on m if and only if m < n when p ‚â§ n. The behavior of solutions in the critical case of q = q c is interesting. The absorption coefficient Œ∑ affects the critical property of solutions with q = q c if and only if p > n: the case q = q c belongs to the global existence situation (regardless of the absorption coefficient Œ∑) if p ‚â§ n; while for q = q c with p > n, the solutions may be both global and non-global, depending on the size of the absorption coefficient.

title: Hopf Bifurcation in Presence of 1 : 3 Resonance
authors: Anna Cima; Jaume Libre; Marco Ant√¥nio Teixeira
abstract: Abstract Assume that the linear part at a singular point p 0 of a C 4 differential system Y 0 in ‚Ñù 4 has eigenvalues ¬±Œ±i and ¬±Œ≤i such that Œ≤/Œ± = 1/3. In the main result of the paper we exhibit a one-parameter family of systems Y Œµ for Œµ ‚àà (-Œ¥ 0 ;+Œ¥ 0 ) where is shown that the original vector field around p 0 can bifurcate in 0, 1, 2, 3 or 4 one-parameter families of periodic orbits. The tool for proving such a result is the averaging theory for non-C 1 differentiable system. Moreover, assuming now that Y Œµ is a one-parameter family of ‚Ñ§ 2 - reversible polynomial vector fields of degree 5, we show that it can bifurcate in 0 or 2 one-parameter families of periodic orbits.

title: On the Global Analytic Integrability of the Belousov‚ÄìZhabotinskii System
abstract: Abstract The well-known Belousov-Zhabotinskii system can be written as ·∫ã = s(x + y - qx 2 - xy), ·∫è = s -1 (-y + fz - xy), ≈º = w(x - z) with f, q, s, w ‚àà ‚Ñù and s ‚â† 0. In this paper we characterize its global analytic first integrals.

title: Multiple Solutions for Resonant Hemivariational Inequalities via Minimax Methods
authors: Sophia Th. Kyritsi; Donal 'Regan; Nikolaos S. Papageorgiou
abstract: Abstract In this paper we consider nonlinear Dirichlet problems driven by the p-Laplacian differential operator with a nonsmooth potential (hemivariational inequalities). We assume that the problem is resonant at infinity with respect to Œª1 > 0 (the principal eigenvalue of the Dirichlet p-Lapalcian) from the right. Using minimax methods based on the nonsmooth critical point theory we prove an existence and a multiplicity theorem.

title: On Singular Liouville Equations and Systems
abstract: Abstract We consider some singular Liouville equations and systems motivated by uniformization problems in a non-smooth setting, as well as from models in mathematical physics. We will study the existence of solutions from a variational point of view, using suitable improvements of the Moser‚ÄìTrudinger inequality. These reduce the problem to a topological one by studying the concentration property of conformal volume, which will be constrained by the functional inequalities of geometric flavour. We will mainly describe some common strategies from the papers [11, 12, 20] in simple situations to give an idea to the non-expert reader about the general methods we use.

title: The Œ≤-Flatness Condition in CR Spheres
abstract: Abstract This work is an adaptation of one of the methods based on the variational critical points at infinity theory of Abbas Bahri [1, 3, 2, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8] to the Cauchy‚ÄìRiemann settings. Following Gamara [24], we give new existence results for the Kazdan‚ÄìWarner problem on Cauchy‚ÄìRiemann spheres, whereas multiplicity results will be discussed in a forthcoming paper. Using algebraic topological methods and the theory of critical points at infinity, we provide a variety of functions which can be realized as the scalar curvature for these manifolds.

title: Some Remarks on the Lie Derivative and the Pullback Equation for Contact Forms
authors: Bernard Dacorogna; Olivier Kneuss; Wladimir Neves

title: Existence of Prograde Double-Double Orbits in the Equal-Mass Four-Body Problem
abstract: Abstract By introducing simple topological constraints and applying a binary decomposition method, we show the existence of a set of prograde double-double orbits for any rotation angle <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>Œ∏</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àà</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>œÄ</m:mi> <m:mo>/</m:mo> <m:mn>7</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">]</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {\theta\in(0,\pi/7]} in the equal-mass four-body problem. A new geometric argument is introduced to show that for any <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>Œ∏</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àà</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>œÄ</m:mi> <m:mo>/</m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {\theta\in(0,\pi/2)} , the action of the minimizer corresponding to the prograde double-double orbit is strictly greater than the action of the minimizer corresponding to the retrograde double-double orbit. This geometric argument can also be applied to study orbits in the planar three-body problem, such as the retrograde orbits, the prograde orbits, the Schubart orbit and the H√©non orbit.

title: Semiclassical Limit For the Nonlinear Klein Gordon Equation in Bounded Domains
abstract: Abstract We are interested in the existence of standing waves for the nonlinear Klein Gordon equation Œµ 2 ‚ñ°œà + W π(œà) = 0 in a bounded domain D. A standing wave has the form œà(t, x) = u(x)e- iwt/Œµ ; for these solutions the Klein Gordon equation becomes We want to use a Benci-Cerami type argument in order to prove a the existence of several standing waves localized in suitable points of D. The main result of this paper is that, under suitable growth condition on W, for Œµ suffciently small, we have at least cat(D) stationary solutions of equation (‚Ä†), where cat(D) is the Ljusternik-Schnirelmann category. The proof is achieved by solving a constrained critical point problem via variational techniques.

title: Extinction for a Singular Diffusion Equation with Strong Gradient Absorption Revisited
abstract: Abstract When <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>N</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>/</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>N</m:mi> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo><</m:mo> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo><</m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> {2N/(N+1)<p<2} and <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo><</m:mo> <m:mi>q</m:mi> <m:mo><</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo>/</m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {0<q<p/2} , non-negative solutions to the singular diffusion equation with gradient absorption <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:msub> <m:mo>‚àÇ</m:mo> <m:mi>t</m:mi> </m:msub> <m:mo>‚Å°</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:msub> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œî</m:mi> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:msub> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">|</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚àá</m:mo> <m:mo>‚Å°</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">|</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mi>q</m:mi> </m:msup> </m:mrow> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true"> </m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mtext>in </m:mtext> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">‚àû</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>√ó</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi> <m:mi>N</m:mi> </m:msup> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> \partial_{t}u-\Delta_{p}u+|\nabla u|^{q}=0\quad\text{in }(0,\infty)\times% \mathbb{R}^{N} vanish after a finite time. This phenomenon is usually referred to as finite-time extinction and takes place provided the initial condition <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msub> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:msub> </m:math> {u_{0}} decays sufficiently rapidly as <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">|</m:mo> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">|</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo>‚Üí</m:mo> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">‚àû</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:math> {|x|\to\infty} . On the one hand, the optimal decay of <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msub> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:msub> </m:math> {u_{0}} at infinity guaranteeing the occurrence of finite-time extinction is identified. On the other hand, assuming further that <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mo><</m:mo> <m:mi>q</m:mi> <m:mo><</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo>/</m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {p-1<q<p/2} , optimal extinction rates near the extinction time are derived.

title: Klein‚ÄìGordon‚ÄìMaxwell Systems with Nonconstant Coupling Coefficient
abstract: We study a Klein-Gordon-Maxwell system, in a bounded spatial domain, under Neumann boundary conditions on the electric potential. We allow a nonconstant coupling coefficient. For sufficiently small data, we find infinitely many static solutions.

title: Topological Translations and Nonlinear Resonance
abstract: Abstract In this paper we study resonance for nonlinear oscillators from a topological point of view. The Poincar√© map associated to a linear second order equation at resonance is a translation of the plane. Our aim is to prove that in the case of nonlinear equations the Poincar√© map is topologically conjugate to a translation. The proof is based on a characterization of translations in terms of Lyapunov functions.

title: Existence and Concentration of Positive Solutions For Coupled Nonlinear Schr√∂dinger Systems in ‚Ñù<sup>N</sup>
abstract: Abstract The aim of this paper is to study the existence and concentration of positive solutions for the coupled nonlinear Schr√∂dinger system where Œµ is a small positive number, N ‚â• 3, p, q > 1 satisfy and W(x), Q(x), K(x) are continuous and bounded positive functions defined in ‚Ñù N . Combining the dual variational methods with mountain pass theorem, we prove under some conditions on W, Q, K the existence of a family of positive solutions concentrating at a point where related functionals achieve their minimum energy.

title: Existence and Multiplicity of Positive Solutions For a Class of Elliptic Boundary Value Problems in the Half-Space
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we prove that if b(x) satisfies some suitable conditions, then -Œîu + u = b(x)u p in ‚Ñù N + with the boundary condition u(x π, 0) = Œªg(x π) has at least two positive solutions if 0 < Œª < Œª*, a minimal positive solution if Œª = Œª* and no positive solution if Œª > Œª*.

title: New Results About the Lambda Constant and Ground States of the ùëä-Functional
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we study properties of the lambda constants and the existence of ground states of Perelman‚Äôs famous W -functional from a variational formulation. We have two kinds of results. One is about the estimation of the lambda constant of G. Perelman, and the other is about the existence of ground states of his W -functional, both on a complete non-compact Riemannian manifold <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mi>M</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>g</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> {(M,g)} . One consequence of our estimation is that, on an ALE (or asymptotic flat) manifold <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mi>M</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>g</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> {(M,g)} , if the scalar curvature s of <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mi>M</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>g</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> {(M,g)} is non-negative and has quadratical decay at infinity, then M is scalar flat, i.e., <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>s</m:mi> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> {s=0} in M . We also introduce a new constant <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>d</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mi>M</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>g</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {d(M,g)} . For the existence of the ground states, we use Lions‚Äô concentration-compactness method.

title: Strong Maximum Principle for Some Quasilinear Dirichlet Problems Having Natural Growth Terms
abstract: Abstract In this paper, dedicated to Laurent Veron, we prove that the Strong Maximum Principle holds for solutions of some quasilinear elliptic equations having lower order terms with quadratic growth with respect to the gradient of the solution.

title: Positive Solutions for Systems of Quasilinear Equations with Non-homogeneous Operators and Weights
authors: Marta Garc√≠a‚ÄêHuidobro; Ra√∫l Man√°sevich; Satoshi Tanaka
abstract: Abstract In this paper we deal with positive radially symmetric solutions for a boundary value problem containing a strongly nonlinear operator. The proof of existence of positive solutions that we give uses the blow-up method as a main ingredient for the search of a-priori bounds of solutions. The blow-up argument is one by contradiction and uses a sort of scaling, reminiscent to the one used in the theory of minimal surfaces, see [B. Gidas and J. Spruck, A priori bounds for positive solutions of nonlinear elliptic equations, Comm. Partial Differential Equations 6 1981, 883‚Äì901], and therefore the homogeneity of the operators, Laplacian or p -Laplacian, and second members powers or power like functions play a fundamental role in the method. Thus, when the differential operators are no longer homogeneous, and similarly for the second members, applying the blow-up method to obtain a-priori bounds of solutions seems an almost impossible task. In spite of this fact, in [M. Garc√≠a-Huidobro, I. Guerra and R. Man√°sevich, Existence of positive radial solutions for a weakly coupled system via blow up, Abstr. Appl. Anal. 3 1998, 1‚Äì2, 105‚Äì131], we were able to overcome this difficulty and obtain a-priori bounds for a certain (simpler) type of problems. We show in this paper that the asymptotically homogeneous functions provide, in the same sense, a nonlinear rescaling, that allows us to generalize the blow-up method to our present situation. After the a-priori bounds are obtained, the existence of a solution follows from Leray‚ÄìSchauder topological degree theory.

title: Existence of Positive Ground State Solutions for Choquard Systems
authors: Yinbin Deng; Qingfei Jin; Wei Shuai
abstract: Abstract We study the existence of positive ground state solution for Choquard systems. In the autonomous case, we prove the existence of at least one positive ground state solution by the Pohozaev manifold method and symmetric-decreasing rearrangement arguments. Moreover, we show that each positive ground state solution is radial symmetric. While, in the nonautonomous case, a positive ground state solution is obtained by using a monotonicity trick and a global compactness lemma. We remark that, under our assumptions of the nonlinearity <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msub> <m:mi>W</m:mi> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:msub> </m:math> {W_{u}} , the search of ground state solutions cannot be reduced to the study of critical points of a functional restricted to a Nehari manifold.

</m:math> {\mathbb{R}^{N},N\geq 3} . More specifically we prove that, for p near the critical exponent <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mn>22</m:mn> <m:mo>*</m:mo> </m:msup> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>4</m:mn> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>N</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>/</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>N</m:mi> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {22^{*}=4N/(N-2)} , the number of positive solutions is estimated below by topological invariants of the domain Œ©: the Ljusternick‚ÄìSchnirelmann category and the Poincar√© polynomial. With respect to the case involving semilinear equations, many difficulties appear here and the classical procedure does not apply immediately. We obtain also en passant some new results concerning the critical case.

title: Multiple Periodic Solutions of a Class of Fractional Laplacian Equations
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we study the existence of multiple periodic solutions for the following fractional equation: <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œî</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mi>s</m:mi> </m:msup> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mi>F</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Ä≤</m:mo> </m:msup> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mo rspace="22.5pt">,</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mi>T</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true"> </m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àà</m:mo> <m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>.</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> (-\Delta)^{s}u+F^{\prime}(u)=0,\qquad u(x)=u(x+T)\quad x\in\mathbb{R}. For an even double-well potential, we establish more and more periodic solutions for a large period T . Without the evenness of F we give the existence of two periodic solutions of the problem. We make use of variational arguments, in particular Clark‚Äôs theorem and Morse theory.

title: Existence of solutions to contact mean-field games of first order
abstract: Abstract This paper deals with the existence of solutions of a class of contact mean-field game systems of first order consisting of a contact Hamilton-Jacobi equation and a continuity equation. Evans found a connection between Hamilton-Jacobi equations and continuity equations from the weak KAM point of view, where the coupling term is zero. Inspired by his work, we prove the main existence result by analyzing the properties of the Mather set for contact Hamiltonian systems.

title: Weighted critical exponents of Sobolev-type embeddings for radial functions
abstract: Abstract In this article, we prove the upper weighted critical exponents for some embeddings from weighted Sobolev spaces of radial functions into weighted Lebesgue spaces. We also consider the lower critical exponent for certain embedding.

title: Least energy sign-changing solutions for Schr√∂dinger-Poisson systems with potential well

V\left(x),K\left(x) have finite limits as <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mo>‚à£</m:mo> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo>‚à£</m:mo> <m:mo>‚Üí</m:mo> <m:mi>‚àû</m:mi> </m:math> | x| \to \infty satisfying some mild assumptions. By combining variational methods with the global compactness lemma, we obtain a least energy sign-changing solution with exactly two nodal domains, and its energy is strictly larger than twice that of least energy solutions.

title: Gradient estimate of the solutions to Hessian equations with oblique boundary value
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we study Hessian equations with the prescribed contact angle boundary value or oblique derivative boundary value and finally derive the a priori global gradient estimate for the admissible solutions.

title: Regularity of degenerate k-Hessian equations on closed Hermitian manifolds
abstract: Abstract In this article, we are concerned with the existence of weak <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>C</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>1</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> {C}^{1,1} solution of the <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>k</m:mi> </m:math> k -Hessian equation on a closed Hermitian manifold under the optimal assumption of the function in the right-hand side of the equation. The key points are to show the weak <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>C</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>1</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> {C}^{1,1} estimates. We prove a Cherrier-type inequality to obtain the <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>C</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> {C}^{0} estimate, and the complex Hessian estimate is proved by using an auxiliary function, which was motivated by Hou et al. and Tosatti and Weinkove. Our result generalizes the K√§hler case proved by Dinew et al.

title: A Correction and an Extension of Stampacchia‚Äôs Work on the Geometric BVP
abstract: Abstract G. Stampacchia introduced the geometric boundary value problem for ODEs in his doctoral thesis and published four papers related to it. Here we point out that the proof of his last theorem on the subject is incorrect and we provide a substitute for it as well as a generalizations of some of his earlier results.

title: A Proposed Model in which Solitons Exhibit Electron and Proton-like Behavior
abstract: Abstract A classical model is proposed in which two nonlinear Klein‚ÄìGordon fields interact via the electromagnetic field. Scaling is such that solitons in the two fields can be interpreted as electrons and protons, respectively. Even though the masses are very different, the magnitude of the charge of the electron-like soliton is the same as that of the proton-like soliton. Attraction and repulsion occur in the desired way through the interaction with the electromagnetic field.

title: Dynamics of the Third Exotic Contact Form on the Sphere Along a Vector Field in its Kernel
abstract: Abstract In this paper we study the dynamics of the third exotic contact form of Gonzalo and Varela [5] on <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mi>S</m:mi> <m:mn>3</m:mn> </m:msup> </m:math> ${S^{3}}$ in the framework of contact form geometry. This dynamics has an impact on the variational problem associated to the contact form such as the violation of the Fredholm condition and the Morse indices of different periodic orbits.

title: A Continuation Approach to the Periodic Boundary Value Problem for a Class of Nonlinear Coupled Oscillators with Potential Depending on Time
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we prove a new continuation theorem for the solvability of periodic boundary value problems for nonlinear vector equations. By applying the continuation theorem, we prove the existence of a periodic solution for a class of semi-linear weekly-coupled systems with time-dependent potential.

title: Bifurcating Nodoids in Hyperbolic Space
abstract: Abstract Consider in hyperbolic space ‚Ñç 3 the one parameter family of immersed (non embedded) constant mean curvature surfaces of revolution DœÄ with constant mean curvature H > 1. The parameter œÄ ‚àà (‚àí‚àû, 0) is the analogue of the ‚Äúnecksize‚Äù of the Delaunay surfaces in Euclidean space. It is proved that when œÄ ‚Üí -‚àû, there exists a branch of surfaces with constant mean curvature H which bifurcate from D œÄ . Furthermore, we prove that these new surfaces have only a discrete group of symmetries. The proof consists in a detailed study of the behaviour of the eigenvalues of the Jacobi operator when œÄ tends to ‚àí ‚àû, together the bifurcation theorem of Crandall-Rabinowitz.

title: Five Gaps in Mathematics
abstract: Abstract In this article we present a careful survey and critique of 5 landmark results and methods that seem to have played a pivotal role in the development of Mathematics since 1984. This article conveys the slow development of our understanding over the years and could not have been possible without the numerous communications with some authors of these articles as well as conversations with other friends and collaborators. The key contribution and the kindness of these colleagues is hereby gratefully acknowledged.

title: Infinitely Many Sign-changing Solutions for Quasilinear Elliptic Systems in ‚Ñù<sup>N</sup>
abstract: Abstract In this paper, by using a perturbation method together with the method of invariant sets of descending flow, we obtain the existence of infinitely many sign-changing solutions of quasilinear elliptic systems in ‚Ñù N .

title: Extremal, Nodal and Stable Solutions for Nonlinear Elliptic Equations
abstract: Abstract We consider Dirichlet p-Laplacian equations which may be resonant with respect to the principal eigenvalue at ¬±‚àû. We show the existence of extremal nontrivial constant sign solutions and of nodal solutions. In the semilinear case (p = 2) we produce additional nodal solutions. We show that certain parametric equations (eigenvalue problems) studied in the past, are a special case of our multiplicity theorem. Finally, we establish the stability of the extremal solutions.

title: Collapse for the Generalized Three-Dimensional Nonlocal Nonlinear Schr√∂dinger Equations
abstract: Abstract Finite time collapse of solutions to the generalized three-dimensional nonlocal nonlinear Schr√∂dinger equations is studied. This result is achieved through establishing some a priori estimates for the nonlocal terms and by introducing a type of virial identities.

title: Global Smooth Solutions for the Zakharov System with Quantum Effects in Two Space Dimensions
authors: Zaihui Gan; Ting Zhong; Boling Guo
abstract: Abstract We consider the Zakharov system with quantum effects in the framework of the scalar mode in two space dimensions iE t + ŒîE = nE + ŒìŒî 2 E, n t = ‚àí‚àá ¬∑ V, (ZSQ) V t = ‚àí‚àán ‚àí ‚àá|E| 2 + Œì‚àáŒîn, which is related to quantum corrections to the Zakharov system for Langmuir waves in plasma. We prove the existence and uniqueness of global smooth solutions to the Cauchy problem for (ZSQ) in the Sobolev space through making a priori integral esimates and utilizing the so-called continuity method.

title: Nonlocal Robin Problem for Elliptic Quasilinear Second Order Equations
abstract: Abstract We investigate the behavior of weak solutions to the nonlocal Robin problem for quasilinear elliptic divergence second order equations in a neighborhood of the boundary corner point. We find an exponent of the solution decreasing rate near the boundary corner point.

title: Effect of a Gradient Term on the Solvability of the Heat Equation with a Supercritical Reaction with Respect to the Hardy Potential
authors: Boumediene Abdellaoui; Ahmed Attar; Susana Merch√°n; Ireneo Peral

title: A Pseudo-gradient Flow Arising In Contact Form Geometry
abstract: Abstract In this work we construct a pseudo-gradient flow on a subspace C Œ≤ of the dual Legendrian curves on a closed contact 3-manifold. These results improve and refine earlier results proved in this framework by A. Bahri [3]. The variational problem involved is not compact, thus asymptotes and critical points at infinity might occur. The flow in this work deforms curves in C Œ≤ into a special set U k‚àà‚Ñï Œì 2k of curves at infinity and thus allows us a better understanding of this non-compact problem.

title: A Determining Form for a Nonlocal System
abstract: Abstract This work is concerned with constructing a finite dimensional form (named determining form) by adding a feedback control term through an interpolation operator. The dynamics of the determining form is consistent with those of the original system.

title: Existence and Asymptotic Profile of Nodal Solutions to Supercritical Problems

title: A Linking/S<sup>1</sup>-equivariant Variational Argument in the Space of Dual Legendrian Curves and the Proof of the Weinstein Conjecture on S<sup>3</sup> ‚Äùin the Large‚Äù
abstract: Abstract Let Œ± be a contact form on S 3 , let Œæ be its Reeb vector-field and let v be a non-singular vector-field in ker Œ±. Let C Œ≤ be the space of curves x on S 3 such ·∫ã = aŒæ + bv, »ß = 0, a ‚â© 0. Let L + , respectively L ‚àí , be the set of curves in C Œ≤ such that b ‚â• 0, respectively b ‚â§ 0. Let, for x ‚àà C Œ≤ , J(x) = ‚à´ 0 1 Œ± x (·∫ã)dt. The framework of the present paper has been introduced previously in eg [3]. We establish in this paper that some cycles (an infinite number of them, indexed by odd integers, tending to ‚àû) in the S 1 - equivariant homology of C Œ≤ , relative to L + ‚à™ L ‚àí and to some specially designed ‚Äùbottom set‚Äù, see section 4, are achieved in the Morse complex of (J,C Œ≤ ) by unions of unstable manifolds of critical points (at infinity)which must include periodic orbits of Œæ; ie unions of unstable manifolds of critical points at infinity alone cannot achieve these cycles. At the odd indexes (2k‚àí1) = 1+(2k‚àí2), 1 for the linking, (2k‚àí2) for the S 1 -equivariance, we find that the equivariant contributions of a critical point at infinity to L + and to L ‚àí are fundamentally asymmetric when compared to those of a periodic orbit [5]. The topological argument of existence of a periodic orbit for Œæ turns out therefore to be surprisingly close, in spirit, to the linking/equivariant argument of P. Rabinowitz in [12]; e.g. the definition of the ‚Äùbottom sets‚Äù of section 4 can be related in part to the linking part in the argument of [12]. The objects and the frameworks are strikingly different, but the original proof of [12] can be recognized in our proof, which uses degree theory, the Fadell-Rabinowitz index [8] and the fact that œÄ n+1 (S n ) = Z 2 , n ‚â• 3. We need of course to prove, in our framework, that these topological classes cannot be achieved by critical points at infinity only, periodic orbits of Œæ excluded, and this is the fundamental difficulty. The arguments hold under the basic assumption that no periodic orbit of index 1 connects L + and L ‚àí . It therefore follows from the present work that either a periodic orbit of index 1 connects L + and L ‚àí (as is probably the case for all three dimensional over-twisted [8] contact forms, see the work of H. Hofer [10], the periodic orbit found in [10] should be of index 1 in the present framework); or (with a flavor of exclusion in either/or) a linking/ equivariant variational argument a la P. Rabinowitz [12] can be put to work. Existence of (possibly multiple) periodic orbits of Œæ, maybe of high Morse index, follows then. Therefore, to a certain extent, the present result runs, especially in the case of threedimensional over-twisted [8] contact forms, against the existence of non-trivial algebraic invariants defined by the periodic orbits of Œæ and independent of what ker Œ± and/or Œ± are.

We prove that the stable critical points of the mean curvature of the boundary generates <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mi>H</m:mi> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:msup> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mi>M</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> ${H^{1}(M)}$ solutions for the following singularly perturbed elliptic problem with Neumann boundary conditions: <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mi>Œµ</m:mi> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:msup> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:msub> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œî</m:mi> <m:mi>g</m:mi> </m:msub> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mtext> in </m:mtext> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>M</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo rspace="12.5pt">,</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mtext> in </m:mtext> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>M</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo rspace="12.5pt">,</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mfrac> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚àÇ</m:mo> <m:mo>‚Å°</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚àÇ</m:mo> <m:mo>‚Å°</m:mo> <m:mi>ŒΩ</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mfrac> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mtext> on </m:mtext> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚àÇ</m:mo> <m:mo>‚Å°</m:mo> <m:mi>M</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>,</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> $-\varepsilon^{2}\Delta_{g}u+u=u^{p-1}\text{ in }M,\quad u>0\text{ in }M,\quad% \frac{\partial u}{\partial\nu}=0\text{ on }\partial M,$ when Œµ is small enough. Here p is subcritical.

title: Optimal Functional Inequalities for Fractional Operators on the Sphere and Applications
abstract: This paper is devoted to the family of optimal functional inequalities on the n-dimensional sphere Ìïän , namely ‚à•F‚à•Lq‚Å¢(Ìïän)2-‚à•F‚à•L2‚Å¢(Ìïän)2q-2‚â§Ìñ¢q,s‚Å¢‚à´ÌïänF‚Å¢‚Ñís‚Å¢F‚Å¢ÌëëŒº for all‚Å¢F‚ààHs/2‚Å¢(Ìïän), where ‚Ñís denotes a fractional Laplace operator of order s‚àà(0,n) , q‚àà[1,2)‚à™(2,q‚ãÜ] , q‚ãÜ=2‚Å¢nn-s is a critical exponent, and d‚Å¢Œº is the uniform probability measure on Ìïän . These inequalities are established with optimal constants using spectral properties of fractional operators. Their consequences for fractional heat flows are considered. If q>2 , these inequalities interpolate between fractional Sobolev and subcritical fractional logarithmic Sobolev inequalities, which correspond to the limit case as q‚Üí2 . For q<2 , the inequalities interpolate between fractional logarithmic Sobolev and fractional Poincar√© inequalities. In the subcritical range q<q‚ãÜ , the method also provides us with remainder terms which can be considered as an improved version of the optimal inequalities. The case s‚àà(-n,0) is also considered. Finally, weighted inequalities involving the fractional Laplacian are obtained in the Euclidean space, by using the stereographic projection.

title: Homogenization of oblique boundary value problems
abstract: Abstract We consider a nonlinear Neumann problem, with periodic oscillation in the elliptic operator and on the boundary condition. Our focus is on problems posed in half-spaces, but with general normal directions that may not be parallel to the directions of periodicity. As the frequency of the oscillation grows, quantitative homogenization results are derived. When the homogenized operator is rotation-invariant, we prove the H√∂lder continuity of the homogenized boundary data. While we follow the outline of Choi and Kim ( Homogenization for nonlinear PDEs in general domains with oscillatory Neumann boundary data , Journal de Math√©matiques Pures et Appliqu√©es 102 (2014), no. 2, 419‚Äì448), new challenges arise due to the presence of tangential derivatives on the boundary condition in our problem. In addition, we improve and optimize the rate of convergence within our approach. Our results appear to be new even for the linear oblique problem.

title: A Carleman inequality on product manifolds and applications to rigidity problems
abstract: Abstract In this article, we prove a Carleman inequality on a product manifold <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>M</m:mi> <m:mo>√ó</m:mo> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi> </m:math> M\times {\mathbb{R}} . As applications, we prove that (1) a periodic harmonic function on <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> {{\mathbb{R}}}^{2} that decays faster than all exponential rate in one direction must be constant 0, (2) a periodic minimal hypersurface in <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>3</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> {{\mathbb{R}}}^{3} that has an end asymptotic to a hyperplane faster than all exponential rate in one direction must be a hyperplane, and (3) a periodic translator in <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>3</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> {{\mathbb{R}}}^{3} that has an end asymptotic to a hyperplane faster than all exponential rates in one direction must be a translating hyperplane.

title: Pinched hypersurfaces are compact
authors: Theodora Bourni; Mat Langford; Stephen Lynch
abstract: Abstract We make rigorous and old idea of using mean curvature flow to prove a theorem of Richard Hamilton on the compactness of proper hypersurfaces with pinched, bounded curvature.

title: On some dense sets in the space of dynamical systems
abstract: Abstract The natural consequence of the existence of different kinds of chaos is the study of their mutual dependence and the relationship between these concepts and the entropy of systems. This observation also applies to the local approach to this issue. In this article, we will focus on this problem in the context of ‚Äúpoints focusing chaos.‚Äù We aim to show their mutual independence by considering the sets of appropriate periodic dynamical systems in the space of discrete dynamical systems.

title: A proof of a trace formula by Richard Melrose
abstract: Abstract The goal of this article is to give a new proof of the wave trace formula proved by Richard Melrose in an impressive article. This trace formula is an extension of the Chazarain-Duistermaat-Guillemin trace formula (denoted as ‚ÄúCDG trace formula‚Äù in this article) to the case of a sub-Riemannian Laplacian on a 3D contact closed manifold. The proof uses a normal form constructed in previous papers, following the pioneering work of Melrose to reduce the case of the invariant Laplacian on the 3D-Heisenberg group. We need also the propagation of singularities results of the works of Ivrii, Lascar, and Melrose.

title: Compactness estimates for minimizers of the Alt-Phillips functional of negative exponents
abstract: Abstract We investigate the rigidity of global minimizers <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo>‚â•</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:math> u\ge 0 of the Alt-Phillips functional involving negative power potentials <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"> <m:munder> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚à´</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ©</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:munder> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚à£</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚àá</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚à£</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚àí</m:mo> <m:mi>Œ≥</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi>œá</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>{</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mo>}</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:msub> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">d</m:mi> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mspace width="1.0em"/> <m:mi>Œ≥</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àà</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo>,</m:mo> </m:math> \mathop{\int }\limits_{\Omega }(| \nabla u{| }^{2}+{u}^{-\gamma }{\chi }_{\left\{u\gt 0\right\}}){\rm{d}}x,\hspace{1.0em}\gamma \in \left(0,2), when the exponent <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>Œ≥</m:mi> </m:math> \gamma is close to the extremes of the admissible values. In particular, we show that global minimizers in <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>n</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> {{\mathbb{R}}}^{n} are one-dimensional if <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>Œ≥</m:mi> </m:math> \gamma is close to 2 and <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>n</m:mi> <m:mo>‚â§</m:mo> <m:mn>7</m:mn> </m:math> n\le 7 , or if <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>Œ≥</m:mi> </m:math> \gamma is close to 0 and <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>n</m:mi> <m:mo>‚â§</m:mo> <m:mn>4</m:mn> </m:math> n\le 4 .

title: Generic properties of the Rabinowitz unbounded continuum
authors: Daniele Bartolucci; Yeyao Hu; Aleks Jevnikar; Wen Yang
abstract: Abstract In this article, we prove that, generically in the sense of domain variations, any solution to a nonlinear eigenvalue problem is either nondegenerate or the Crandall-Rabinowitz transversality condition that is satisfied. We then deduce that, generically, the unbounded Rabinowitz continuum of solutions is a simple analytic curve. The global bifurcation diagram resembles the classic model case of the Gel‚Äôfand problem in two dimensions.

title: Gradient estimates and the fundamental solution for higher-order elliptic systems with lower-order terms
abstract: Abstract We establish the Caccioppoli inequality, a reverse H√∂lder inequality in the spirit of the classic estimate of Meyers, and construct the fundamental solution for linear elliptic differential equations of order <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mn>2</m:mn> <m:mi>m</m:mi> </m:math> 2m with certain lower order terms.

title: A priori bounds, existence, and uniqueness of smooth solutions to an anisotropic L p Minkowski problem for log-concave measure
abstract: Abstract In the present article, we prove the existence and uniqueness of smooth solutions to an anisotropic <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi>L</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msub> </m:math> {L}_{p} Minkowski problem for the log-concave measure. Our proof of the existence is based on the well-known continuous method whose crucial factor is the a priori bounds of an auxiliary problem. The uniqueness is based on a maximum principle argument. It is worth mentioning that apart from the <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>C</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> {C}^{2} bounds of solutions, the <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>C</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> {C}^{1} bounds of solutions also need some efforts since the convexity of <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>S</m:mi> </m:math> S cannot be used directly, which is one of great difference between the classical and the anisotropic versions. Moreover, our result can be seen as an attempt to get new results on the geometric analysis of log-concave measure.
